- Base peak at 212 = M - 35 (Cl atom loss), typical for aryl chlorides

Step 4: Analyze ¹H NMR
- 4.30 & 4.35 ppm (t, 2H each): Two distinct CH₂ groups in similar environments (OCH₂CH₂O)
- 5.50-6.80 ppm (d, d, dd): Vinyl group (CH₂=CH-) with characteristic coupling
- 7.20-8.50 ppm (aromatic region): Six aromatic protons with substitution pattern
- 8.50 ppm (s): Deshielded proton near electronegative atom (pyridine N)

Step 5: Analyze ¹³C NMR
- 64.5 & 65.2 ppm: Oxygenated CH₂ carbons (OCH₂CH₂O)
- 118.0 & 140.0 ppm: Vinyl carbons (CH₂ and CH)
- 122.0-150.0 ppm: Aromatic carbons including quaternary centers

Step 6: HSQC correlations
- Confirm H-C assignments for all protonated carbons
- Reveal two distinct oxygenated CH₂ groups
- Identify vinyl carbon connectivity

Step 7: Assemble structure
- Quinoline core (pyridine fused to benzene) from aromatic signals and N in formula
- Chlorine at position 3 (C-Cl stretch, deshielded aromatic proton)
- Vinyl group at position 4 (alkene signals, HSQC correlations)
- 1,4-Benzodioxane ring (OCH₂CH₂O) fused to benzene portion (two distinct CH₂ signals, aromatic substitution pattern)

Final structure: 4-Vinyl-3-chloro-1,4-benzodioxano[2,3-b]quinoline

question:
A compound with molecular formula C13H17NO4 exhibits the following spectral data:

IR (cm⁻¹): 1735 (s), 1605 (m), 1250 (s), 1180 (m)
Mass Spectrum (m/z): 251 (M⁺, 100%), 206 (M⁺-OEt, 45%), 161 (M⁺-2×OEt, 30%)
¹H NMR (δ, ppm): 7.85 (s, 1H), 7.20 (s, 1H), 4.35 (q, J=7.2 Hz, 2H), 4.15 (q, J=7.2 Hz, 2H), 2.55 (s, 3H), 2.40 (s, 3H), 1.35 (t, J=7.2 Hz, 3H), 1.20 (t, J=7.2 Hz, 3H)
¹³C NMR (δ, ppm): 166.5, 165.8, 150.2, 148.7, 138.5, 132.0, 128.5, 125.0, 62.0, 61.5, 24.0, 14.5, 14.0
HSQC: Cross-peaks confirm correlations between 4.35 ppm (¹H) and 62.0 ppm (¹³C), 4.15 ppm (¹H) and 61.5 ppm (¹³C), 2.55 ppm (¹H) and 24.0 ppm (¹³C), 2.40 ppm (¹H) and 14.5 ppm (¹³C).

Determine the structure of the compound and explain how each spectral feature supports your conclusion.
solution:
Step 1: Calculate degrees of unsaturation.
(2C + 2 - H - X + N)/2 = (26 + 2 - 17 - 0 + 1)/2 = 6 degrees (4 from aromatic ring + 2 from carbonyls).

Step 2: Analyze IR spectrum.
- 1735 cm⁻¹: Ester C=O stretch
- 1605 cm⁻¹: Aromatic C=C or C=N stretch
- 1250 cm⁻¹: C-O stretch of esters

Step 3: Interpret mass spectrum.
- Molecular ion at m/z 251 confirms formula C13H17NO4
- Fragmentation pattern shows sequential loss of two ethoxy groups (45 Da each), indicating two ester functionalities

Step 4: Analyze ¹H NMR.
- Two singlets (2.55 and 2.40 ppm, 3H each): Methyl groups on aromatic ring
- Two quartets (4.35 and 4.15 ppm, 2H each) and two triplets (1.35 and 1.20 ppm, 3H each): Two distinct ethyl ester groups
- Two aromatic protons (7.85 and 7.20 ppm, 1H each): Substituted pyridine ring

Step 5: Analyze ¹³C NMR and HSQC.
- Two carbonyl carbons (166.5 and 165.8 ppm)
- Six aromatic carbons (150.2, 148.7, 138.5, 132.0, 128.5, 125.0 ppm)
- Two ethyl groups (62.0, 61.5, 14.5, 14.0 ppm)
- Methyl carbons (24.0 and 14.5 ppm) correlated to their protons via HSQC

Step 6: Assemble structure.
- Pyridine ring with two methyl substituents (positions 2 and 6)
- Two ester groups at positions 3 and 5 (confirmed by aromatic proton splitting pattern)
- Ethyl ester groups confirmed by ethoxy signals in NMR and MS fragmentation

Final structure: 3,5-diethoxycarbonyl-2,6-dimethylpyridine (SMILES: CCOC(=O)c1cc(C(=O)OCC)c(C)nc1C)

All spectral data are consistent with this structure, with characteristic ester carbonyl stretches in IR, molecular ion in MS, and distinct ethyl/methyl signals in NMR.

question:
A compound with molecular formula C₁₁H₁₂ClNO₃ exhibits the following spectral data:

IR (cm⁻¹): 3300 (broad), 1735 (strong), 1680 (strong), 1600, 1500, 1250, 750
Mass Spectrum: m/z 241 (M⁺, 100%), 243 (M+2, 35%), 226 (M-15), 182 (M-59)
¹H NMR (δ, ppm): 8.20 (br s, 1H, NH), 7.80-7.20 (m, 4H, Ar-H), 4.80 (q, J=6.8 Hz, 1H, CHCl), 3.90 (s, 3H, OCH₃), 1.60 (d, J=6.8 Hz, 3H, CH₃-Cl)
¹³C NMR (δ, ppm): 170.5 (C=O, amide), 168.0 (C=O, ester), 150.2, 134.8, 130.5, 129.8, 127.0, 124.5 (aromatic carbons), 55.0 (CHCl), 52.0 (OCH₃), 20.5 (CH₃-Cl)
HSQC: Correlations observed between 4.80 ppm (¹H) and 55.0 ppm (¹³C), 3.90 ppm (¹H) and 52.0 ppm (¹³C), 1.60 ppm (¹H) and 20.5 ppm (¹³C).

Propose a structure and justify your answer with detailed analysis of each spectrum.
solution:
Step 1: Analyze molecular formula and IR data
- Molecular formula C₁₁H₁₂ClNO₃ indicates 6 degrees of unsaturation (rings + double bonds).
- IR peaks: 1735 cm⁻¹ (ester C=O), 1680 cm⁻¹ (amide C=O), 3300 cm⁻¹ (amide N-H), 1600/1500 cm⁻¹ (aromatic C=C). Confirms ester, amide, and aromatic ring.

Step 2: Interpret mass spectrum
- M⁺ at m/z 241 (matches molecular weight: 11C=132, 12H=12, Cl=35.5, N=14, 3O=48; total 241.5).
- M+2 peak at 243 (35% intensity) confirms chlorine presence (³⁵Cl/³⁷Cl isotope pattern).
- Fragmentation: M-15 (loss of CH₃) suggests methyl ester; M-59 (loss of COOCH₃) confirms ester group.

Step 3: Analyze ¹H NMR
- 8.20 ppm (br s, 1H): Amide NH (exchange broadened).
- 7.80-7.20 ppm (m, 4H): Aromatic protons (two substituents on benzene reduce integration to 4H).
- 4.80 ppm (q, J=6.8 Hz, 1H): CHCl (quartet from adjacent CH₃).
- 3.90 ppm (s, 3H): OCH₃ (ester methyl).
- 1.60 ppm (d, J=6.8 Hz, 3H): CH₃-Cl (doublet from coupling to CHCl).

Step 4: Analyze ¹³C NMR and HSQC
- 170.5 ppm (amide C=O), 168.0 ppm (ester C=O): Confirms carbonyl groups.
- 150.2-124.5 ppm: Six aromatic carbons (two substituted positions).
- 55.0 ppm (CHCl), 52.0 ppm (OCH₃), 20.5 ppm (CH₃-Cl): HSQC confirms proton-carbon assignments.

Step 5: Assemble structure
- Benzene ring with two substituents (aromatic 4H integration).
- Ester group (COOCH₃) and amide group (NHCO) attached to ring.
- Amide side chain: CHCl-CH₃ (quartet/doublet coupling in ¹H NMR).
- Substitution pattern: Ortho arrangement (steric hindrance explains downfield NH shift at 8.20 ppm).

Final structure: Methyl 2-[(2-chloropropanoyl)amino]benzoate (SMILES: COC(=O)c1ccccc1NC(=O)C(C)Cl)

question:
A compound with molecular formula C₁₇H₁₁ClF₃NO₃ exhibits the following spectroscopic data:

**IR (cm⁻¹):** 1725 (s), 1680 (s), 1600 (m), 1150 (s), 1100 (s)
**Mass Spectrum (ESI+):** m/z 369 [M+H]⁺, 334 [M-Cl]⁺, 300 [M-OCF₃]⁺
**¹H NMR (CDCl₃, 400 MHz):** δ 10.05 (s, 1H), 8.12 (d, J=2.0 Hz, 1H), 7.95 (dd, J=8.0, 2.0 Hz, 1H), 7.78 (d, J=8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.55 (d, J=8.5 Hz, 2H), 7.35 (d, J=8.5 Hz, 2H), 4.85 (s, 2H), 4.75 (s, 2H)
**¹³C NMR (CDCl₃, 100 MHz):** δ 190.2, 165.8, 148.5, 138.2, 135.1, 132.5, 131.8, 130.2, 129.5 (q, J=32 Hz), 127.8, 126.5, 123.7 (q, J=270 Hz), 121.5, 118.9, 52.3, 45.6
**HSQC:** Correlations observed between δ 10.05 (¹H) and 190.2 (¹³C), δ 4.85 (¹H) and 52.3 (¹³C), δ 4.75 (¹H) and 45.6 (¹³C).

Determine the molecular structure and justify your conclusion by analyzing all spectroscopic data.
solution:
Step 1: **Mass Spectrum Analysis**
The molecular ion [M+H]⁺ at m/z 369 confirms the molecular formula C₁₇H₁₁ClF₃NO₃ (calculated MW = 369.72 g/mol). Fragment ions at 334 [M-Cl]⁺ and 300 [M-OCF₃]⁺ indicate the presence of a chlorine atom and a trifluoromethoxy group (-OCF₃).

Step 2: **IR Spectrum Interpretation**
- 1725 cm⁻¹: Aldehyde C=O stretch (strong, sharp).
- 1680 cm⁻¹: Amide C=O stretch (lower frequency due to conjugation).
- 1600 cm⁻¹: Aromatic C=C vibrations.
- 1150 and 1100 cm⁻¹: C-F stretches (trifluoromethoxy group).

Step 3: **¹H NMR Analysis**
- δ 10.05 (s, 1H): Aldehyde proton (no coupling, deshielded by electronegative groups).
- Aromatic region (δ 8.12–7.35): Two substituted benzene rings:
  - δ 8.12 (d, J=2.0 Hz), 7.95 (dd, J=8.0, 2.0 Hz), 7.78 (d, J=8.0 Hz): Monosubstituted ring with electron-withdrawing groups (Cl and aldehyde).
  - δ 7.55 (d, J=8.5 Hz), 7.35 (d, J=8.5 Hz): Para-substituted ring with -OCF₃ group.
- δ 4.85 (s, 2H) and 4.75 (s, 2H): Two distinct CH₂ groups (singlets indicate no adjacent protons).

Step 4: **¹³C NMR and HSQC Correlation**
- δ 190.2: Aldehyde carbon (HSQC confirms correlation with δ 10.05).
- δ 165.8: Amide carbonyl (conjugated with aromatic ring).
- δ 123.7 (q, J=270 Hz): CF₃ carbon (quartet due to ¹⁹F coupling).
- δ 52.3 and 45.6: CH₂ carbons (HSQC confirms correlations with δ 4.85 and 4.75).
- Aromatic carbons (δ 148.5–118.9): Substituted benzene rings with Cl and -OCF₃.

Step 5: **Structure Assembly**
- The aldehyde (δ 10.05) and amide carbonyl (δ 165.8) suggest an isoindolinone core.
- The CH₂ groups (δ 4.85 and 4.75) connect the isoindolinone to a para-substituted benzene ring with -OCF₃.
- The chlorine substituent is placed ortho to the aldehyde on the isoindolinone ring (supported by aromatic coupling patterns).

Final Structure: <IUPAC> 5-chloro-2-((4-(trifluoromethoxy)benzyl)-2,3-dihydro-1H-isoindole-1,3-dione </IUPAC> (SMILES: O=Cc1cc(Cl)c2c(c1)CN(Cc1ccc(OC(F)(F)F)cc1)C2=O)

question:
A compound with molecular formula C18H10Cl2FN3O3 exhibits the following spectral data:

**IR (cm⁻¹):** 2220 (sharp), 1680 (broad), 1600, 1580, 1250, 1100, 800, 750.
**Mass Spectrum (m/z):** 477 (M⁺, 100%), 441 (M-Cl, 40%), 257 (base peak).
**¹H NMR (δ ppm, CDCl₃):** 8.21 (d, J=2.0 Hz, 1H), 7.95 (d, J=8.5 Hz, 1H), 7.78 (dd, J=8.5, 2.0 Hz, 1H), 7.62 (d, J=8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.55 (d, J=8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.38 (s, 1H), 4.65 (s, 2H), 8.45 (br s, 1H).
**¹³C NMR (δ ppm):** 165.2, 155.8, 148.7, 142.3, 138.1, 135.4, 132.7, 130.2, 128.9, 127.6, 125.3, 122.1, 118.5, 115.0, 112.4, 45.6.
**HSQC:** Correlations between 4.65 ppm (¹H) and 45.6 ppm (¹³C), 7.38 ppm (¹H) and 112.4 ppm (¹³C), and aromatic proton-carbon pairs.

Determine the molecular structure and justify your answer with spectral correlations.
solution:
Step 1: **Degrees of Unsaturation**
Calculate using (2C + 2 - H - X + N)/2 = (36 + 2 - 10 - 3 + 3)/2 = 14. Indicates multiple rings/π bonds (e.g., two aromatic rings, nitrile, amide, isoxazole).

Step 2: **IR Analysis**
- 2220 cm⁻¹: Nitrile (C≡N).
- 1680 cm⁻¹: Amide C=O (lower than typical due to conjugation).
- 1600/1580 cm⁻¹: Aromatic C=C.
- 1250 cm⁻¹: C-O ether.
- 1100 cm⁻¹: C-F stretch.
- 800/750 cm⁻¹: C-Cl stretches.

Step 3: **Mass Spectrometry**
- M⁺ at 477 matches C18H10Cl2FN3O3 (MW = 477 g/mol).
- M-Cl (441) confirms Cl presence.
- Base peak at 257 suggests a stable aromatic fragment (loss of isoxazole-amide side chain).

Step 4: **¹H NMR Analysis**
- 8.21 (d, 1H), 7.78 (dd, 1H), 7.95 (d, 1H): Ortho-coupled aromatic protons on a monosubstituted benzene ring (ring B: Cl, F, CH2NHCO substituents).
- 7.62 (d, 1H), 7.55 (d, 1H): Meta-coupled protons on a disubstituted benzene ring (ring A: nitrile, Cl, O-aryl).
- 7.38 (s, 1H): Isoxazole ring proton (no adjacent H).
- 4.65 (s, 2H): CH2 group adjacent to electronegative atoms (N and aromatic ring).
- 8.45 (br s, 1H): Amide NH (exchangeable, broad).

Step 5: **¹³C NMR & HSQC**
- 165.2 ppm: Amide carbonyl (C=O).
- 155.8 ppm: Ether-linked aromatic carbon (C-O).
- 115.0 ppm: Nitrile carbon (C≡N).
- 112.4 ppm: Isoxazole carbon bonded to H (HSQC correlation with 7.38 ppm).
- 45.6 ppm: CH2 group (HSQC correlation with 4.65 ppm).

Step 6: **Structure Assembly**
- Two aromatic rings (A and B) linked by an ether (C-O at 1250 cm⁻¹, 155.8 ppm).
- Ring A: 1,3,5-substituted with nitrile (IR, 115.0 ppm), Cl, and O-aryl.
- Ring B: 1,2,4-substituted with Cl, F (1100 cm⁻¹), and CH2NHCO (amide at 1680 cm⁻¹, 165.2 ppm).
- CH2NHCO connects to an isoxazole ring (1H singlet at 7.38 ppm, 112.4 ppm).

Final Structure: N#Cc1cc(Cl)cc(Oc2c(Cl)ccc(CNC(=O)c3ccno3)c2F)c1

question:
A compound with molecular formula C₂₃H₂₄ClF₃N₆O₂ exhibits the following spectral data:

IR (cm⁻¹): 3200 (broad), 1710, 1680, 1320, 1150
Mass Spectrum: m/z 508 [M]⁺, 510 [M+2]⁺, 451 [M−C₄H₉]⁺
¹H NMR (δ, ppm): 0.90 (t, J=7.2 Hz, 3H), 1.32 (m, 2H), 1.60 (m, 2H), 2.75 (t, J=7.5 Hz, 2H), 3.95 (t, J=7.2 Hz, 2H), 5.40 (s, 2H), 7.25 (d, J=8.1 Hz, 1H), 7.55 (dd, J=8.1, 1.8 Hz, 1H), 7.65 (d, J=1.8 Hz, 1H), 7.80 (s, 1H), 8.10 (s, 1H), 12.10 (br s, 1H)
¹³C NMR (δ, ppm): 13.8, 20.1, 28.7, 30.5, 44.2, 50.3, 109.4, 115.2 (q, J=32 Hz), 121.8, 123.1, 125.0 (q, J=270 Hz), 128.3, 130.1, 134.6, 138.2, 142.7, 150.5, 155.8, 160.2, 165.4
HSQC: Correlations between ¹H and ¹³C signals confirm direct C-H connections.

Using this data, determine the structure and explain how each spectral feature supports your conclusion.
solution:
Step 1: Calculate degrees of unsaturation. For C₂₃H₂₄ClF₃N₆O₂: (2×23 + 2 - 24 - 4 + 6)/2 = 13. This indicates multiple rings/π-bonds.

Step 2: Analyze IR data. Peaks at 1710 and 1680 cm⁻¹ indicate two carbonyl groups (likely amides/imides). Broad 3200 cm⁻¹ suggests N-H stretching. 1320 and 1150 cm⁻¹ correspond to C-F vibrations.

Step 3: Interpret mass spectrum. Molecular ion at 508/510 (3:1 ratio) confirms Cl presence. Fragment at 451 results from loss of butyl group (C₄H₉, 57 Da), indicating a butyl substituent.

Step 4: Assign ¹H NMR signals:
- 0.90 (t), 1.32 (m), 1.60 (m), 3.95 (t): Butyl chain (N-CH₂CH₂CH₂CH₃)
- 2.75 (t): Propyl CH₂ adjacent to aromatic system
- 5.40 (s): Benzyl CH₂ group
- 7.25-7.65: Aromatic protons (trisubstituted benzene with CF₃)
- 7.80, 8.10: Imidazole ring protons
- 12.10 (br s): NH proton from imidazole or amide

Step 5: Analyze ¹³C NMR:
- 165.4 and 160.2: Two carbonyl carbons
- 125.0 (q, J=270 Hz): CF₃ carbon
- 115.2 (q, J=32 Hz): Aromatic carbon adjacent to CF₃
- 50.3: Benzyl CH₂
- 44.2: N-CH₂ of butyl chain

Step 6: HSQC correlations confirm assignments (e.g., butyl CH₃ at 0.90 ppm correlates with 13.8 ppm carbon).

Step 7: Assemble structure:
- Central purine-like core with two carbonyls (positions 2 and 6) and NH at position 9
- N-1 butyl substituent (confirmed by NMR and MS fragmentation)
- N-7 propyl linker to imidazole ring
- Imidazole C-4 connected to benzyl group with CF₃-substituted benzene
- Chlorine at position 8 (from molecular formula and aromatic substitution pattern)

Final structure matches the SMILES: CCCCn1c(=O)n(CCCc2cn(Cc3cccc(C(F)(F)F)c3)cn2)c(=O)c2[nH]c(Cl)nc21

question:
A compound with molecular formula C₁₆H₁₉NO₂ exhibits the following spectral data:

**IR (cm⁻¹):** 1650 (strong), 1250 (medium), 3050 (weak), 2970 (medium)
**Mass Spectrum (m/z):** 257 (M⁺, 100%), 228 (M-29, 45%), 242 (M-15, 30%)
**¹H NMR (CDCl₃, 400 MHz):** δ 8.32 (d, J=8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.85 (d, J=8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.60-7.45 (m, 4H), 4.05 (s, 3H), 3.50 (q, J=7.0 Hz, 4H), 1.25 (t, J=7.0 Hz, 6H)
**¹³C NMR (CDCl₃, 100 MHz):** δ 170.2, 155.8, 134.2, 132.5, 129.8, 128.7, 127.6, 126.4, 125.3, 124.1, 123.0, 119.9, 61.5, 45.2, 12.8
**HSQC:** Correlations observed between: δ 4.05 (¹H) ↔ δ 61.5 (¹³C); δ 3.50 (¹H) ↔ δ 45.2 (¹³C); δ 1.25 (¹H) ↔ δ 12.8 (¹³C)

Determine the molecular structure and explain how each spectral feature supports your conclusion.
solution:
Step 1: **Degrees of Unsaturation**
Calculate from C₁₆H₁₉NO₂: (2×16 + 2 - 19 + 1)/2 = 8. This indicates a highly unsaturated system (e.g., naphthalene ring + carbonyl).

Step 2: **IR Analysis**
- 1650 cm⁻¹: Amide C=O stretch (lower than ketone due to resonance with N).
- 1250 cm⁻¹: C-O stretch of methoxy group.
- 3050 cm⁻¹: Aromatic C-H.
- 2970 cm⁻¹: Alkyl C-H.

Step 3: **Mass Spectrum**
- M⁺ = 257: Confirms molecular weight.
- m/z 228 (M-29): Loss of ethyl group (CH₂CH₃).
- m/z 242 (M-15): Loss of methyl group (from OCH₃).

Step 4: **¹H NMR Analysis**
- δ 8.32 (d, 1H), 7.85 (d, 1H), 7.60-7.45 (m, 4H): 6 aromatic protons on naphthalene ring (substituted at two positions).
- δ 4.05 (s, 3H): Methoxy group (OCH₃) attached to aromatic ring.
- δ 3.50 (q, 4H) and δ 1.25 (t, 6H): Two equivalent ethyl groups (N-CH₂CH₃), confirmed by integration and splitting.

Step 5: **¹³C NMR & HSQC**
- δ 170.2: Amide carbonyl carbon.
- δ 155.8: Methoxy-substituted aromatic carbon.
- δ 61.5: OCH₃ carbon (correlates with δ 4.05 in HSQC).
- δ 45.2: N-CH₂ (correlates with δ 3.50 in HSQC).
- δ 12.8: CH₃ (correlates with δ 1.25 in HSQC).

Step 6: **Structure Assembly**
- Naphthalene core (6 aromatic protons, 8 degrees of unsaturation).
- Methoxy group at position 1 (δ 4.05, 157 ppm C-O).
- Amide carbonyl at position 2 (δ 170.2, IR 1650 cm⁻¹).
- Diethyl substitution on amide nitrogen (N-CH₂CH₃ groups confirmed by NMR).

**Final Structure:** 1-Methoxy-2-(N,N-diethylcarbamoyl)naphthalene (SMILES: CCN(CC)C(=O)c1ccc2ccccc2c1OC)

question:
Given the molecular formula C₁₀H₁₃NOS₂ and the following spectroscopic data, deduce the molecular structure:

1. **IR Spectrum**: Strong absorption at 1650 cm⁻¹ (broad), 3300 cm⁻¹ (broad), and 720 cm⁻¹.
2. **Mass Spectrum**: Molecular ion peak at m/z 227, with a significant fragment at m/z 212.
3. **¹H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl₃)**: δ 7.20 (d, J = 5.2 Hz, 1H), 6.95 (d, J = 5.2 Hz, 1H), 6.10 (br s, 1H, exchangeable with D₂O), 3.80 (m, 1H), 3.10 (dd, J = 14.0, 4.8 Hz, 1H), 2.95 (dd, J = 14.0, 8.0 Hz, 1H), 2.75 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H), 2.40–2.55 (m, 2H), 1.20 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H).
4. **¹³C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl₃)**: δ 172.5, 142.0, 129.5, 128.0, 123.0, 52.0, 38.5, 35.0, 28.0, 10.5.
5. **HSQC Spectrum**: Correlations between: (i) δ 3.80 (¹H) and δ 52.0 (¹³C), (ii) δ 2.75 (¹H) and δ 28.0 (¹³C), (iii) δ 1.20 (¹H) and δ 10.5 (¹³C).

Provide a step-by-step analysis to determine the structure.
solution:
Step 1: **Degrees of Unsaturation**
Calculate from C₁₀H₁₃NOS₂: 
(2C + 2 - H - X + N)/2 = (20 + 2 - 13 - 0 + 1)/2 = 5. 
Indicates 5 double bond equivalents (rings + π-bonds).

Step 2: **IR Analysis**
- 1650 cm⁻¹ (broad): Amide C=O stretch.
- 3300 cm⁻¹ (broad): N-H stretch (amide).
- 720 cm⁻¹: C-S stretch (common in thiophene or thioether).

Step 3: **Mass Spectrum**
- Molecular ion at m/z 227 matches C₁₀H₁₃NOS₂ (12×10 + 1×13 + 14 + 16 + 32×2 = 227).
- Fragment at m/z 212: Loss of CH₃• (15 Da) from the amide's propyl group.

Step 4: **¹H NMR Analysis**
- δ 7.20 (d, J = 5.2 Hz, 1H) and 6.95 (d, J = 5.2 Hz, 1H): Thiophene ring protons (ortho-coupled).
- δ 6.10 (br s): Exchangeable N-H proton (amide).
- δ 3.80 (m): Methine proton (CH) adjacent to electronegative N and S.
- δ 3.10 (dd) and 2.95 (dd): Diastereotopic CH₂ protons adjacent to S (thioether).
- δ 2.75 (t, J = 7.2 Hz): CH₂ adjacent to carbonyl (amide).
- δ 1.20 (t, J = 7.2 Hz): Terminal methyl group (CH₃) of propyl chain.

Step 5: **¹³C NMR and HSQC**
- δ 172.5: Amide carbonyl (C=O).
- δ 142.0, 129.5, 128.0, 123.0: Thiophene ring carbons.
- δ 52.0: Methine carbon (CH) bonded to N and S (HSQC confirms correlation with δ 3.80).
- δ 38.5 and 35.0: CH₂ carbons adjacent to S and carbonyl.
- δ 28.0: CH₂ in propyl chain (HSQC confirms correlation with δ 2.75).
- δ 10.5: Terminal methyl carbon (HSQC confirms correlation with δ 1.20).

Step 6: **Structure Assembly**
- Thiophene ring (from aromatic ¹H/¹³C signals and IR C-S).
- Amide group (IR, ¹H N-H, ¹³C C=O).
- Propyl chain (ethyl triplet and quartet in ¹H, confirmed by HSQC).
- Thioether linkage (δ 3.10–2.95, ¹³C 35.0, IR 720 cm⁻¹).
- Bicyclic core: Thiophene fused to a 5-membered ring containing S and N (from degrees of unsaturation and connectivity).

Final Structure: **3-(5,6-Dihydro-4H-thieno[2,3-b]thiopyran-4-yl)propanamide** (SMILES: CCC(=O)NC1CSc2sccc2C1).

question:
A compound with molecular formula C₂₅H₂₈N₂O₅S exhibits the following spectroscopic data:

**IR (cm⁻¹):** 3350 (broad), 1650 (sharp), 1350/1150 (doublet), 1250, 1050.
**Mass Spectrum (m/z):** 468 [M⁺], 439 ([M-29]⁺), 214.
**¹H NMR (CDCl₃, δ ppm):** 1.25 (t, 3H, J=7.2 Hz), 2.45 (s, 3H), 3.40 (q, 2H, J=7.2 Hz), 3.80 (s, 3H), 4.55 (s, 2H), 4.60 (s, 2H), 6.70-6.80 (m, 4H), 6.95-7.10 (m, 6H), 7.30-7.40 (m, 4H), 7.50 (br s, 1H).
**¹³C NMR (CDCl₃, δ ppm):** 12.5, 21.2, 43.8, 52.1, 55.6, 60.3, 114.2, 115.8, 126.7, 127.9, 128.5, 129.3, 130.1, 135.4, 140.2, 155.7, 160.3, 170.5.
**HSQC:** Correlations between 4.55 ppm (¹H) and 60.3 ppm (¹³C); 3.80 ppm (¹H) and 55.6 ppm (¹³C); 2.45 ppm (¹H) and 21.2 ppm (¹³C).

Determine the molecular structure and justify your answer using the provided data.
solution:
Step 1: Analyze molecular formula and degrees of unsaturation.
- C₂₅H₂₈N₂O₅S → 25 carbons, 28 hydrogens, 2 nitrogens, 5 oxygens, 1 sulfur.
- Degrees of unsaturation = (2C + 2 - H - X + N)/2 = (50 + 2 - 28 - 0 + 2)/2 = 13. Indicates multiple rings/π bonds.

Step 2: Interpret IR data.
- 3350 cm⁻¹ (broad): O-H stretch (phenol).
- 1650 cm⁻¹ (sharp): Amide C=O stretch.
- 1350/1150 cm⁻¹ (doublet): Sulfone (SO₂) asymmetric/symmetric stretches.
- 1250 cm⁻¹: C-O stretch (ether).
- 1050 cm⁻¹: C-N stretch (tertiary amine).

Step 3: Analyze mass spectrometry.
- Molecular ion at m/z 468 confirms formula.
- Fragment at m/z 439 ([M-29]⁺): Loss of ethyl group (C₂H₅, 29 Da).
- Fragment at m/z 214: Likely cleavage at sulfonamide N-C bond, retaining the tosyl group.

Step 4: Analyze ¹H NMR.
- 1.25 ppm (t, 3H) & 3.40 ppm (q, 2H): Ethyl group (CH₂CH₃).
- 2.45 ppm (s, 3H): Aromatic methyl (tosyl group).
- 3.80 ppm (s, 3H): Methoxy group (OCH₃).
- 4.55 ppm (s, 2H) & 4.60 ppm (s, 2H): Two benzylic CH₂ groups.
- 6.70-7.40 ppm (multiplets, 14H): Aromatic protons (4 para-substituted rings).
- 7.50 ppm (br s, 1H): Phenolic OH (exchanges with D₂O).

Step 5: Analyze ¹³C NMR and HSQC.
- 12.5 ppm (CH₃), 21.2 ppm (Ar-CH₃), 43.8 ppm (CH₂), 52.1 ppm (CH₂), 55.6 ppm (OCH₃), 60.3 ppm (CH₂).
- 170.5 ppm: Amide carbonyl.
- Aromatic carbons (114.2–160.3 ppm): 4 para-substituted benzene rings.
- HSQC confirms H-C correlations for OCH₃ (3.80/55.6), tosyl CH₃ (2.45/21.2), and benzylic CH₂ (4.55/60.3).

Step 6: Assemble the structure.
- Amide (¹H/¹³C NMR, IR) and sulfonamide (IR, ¹³C NMR) groups present.
- Ethyl group (¹H NMR) attached to tertiary amine (¹³C NMR at 52.1 ppm).
- Phenolic OH (IR, ¹H NMR) on a para-substituted benzene (aromatic splitting).
- Methoxy group (HSQC, ¹H/¹³C NMR) on another para-substituted benzene.
- Tosyl group (SO₂, aromatic CH₃, ¹H/¹³C NMR) attached to sulfonamide nitrogen.
- Final structure: N-ethyl-N-(4-hydroxybenzyl)acetamide linked via a methylene group to N-(4-methoxyphenyl)-4-methylbenzenesulfonamide.

Step 7: Verify with SMILES.
- Matches given SMILES: CCN(Cc1ccc(O)cc1)C(=O)CN(c1ccccc1OC)S(=O)(=O)c1ccccc1C.

question:
Given the molecular formula C₁₆H₁₅Cl₂NO₅S and the following spectral data, determine the molecular structure. Provide a step-by-step analysis of each spectrum and explain how the data collectively confirm the structure.

IR (cm⁻¹): 3300 (broad), 1650 (sharp), 1350 (strong), 1150 (strong), 1250 (medium), 1600 (medium).
Mass Spectrum (m/z): 403 (M⁺, 1:1 doublet), 368 (M−35), 339 (M−64).
¹H NMR (δ, ppm): 8.2 (1H, s, NH), 7.6–7.4 (4H, m, aromatic), 7.2–7.0 (3H, m, aromatic), 4.8 (2H, s, OCH₂CO), 3.8 (2H, t, J=6.5 Hz, CH₂SO₂), 3.6 (2H, t, J=6.5 Hz, CH₂OH), 2.2 (1H, br s, OH).
¹³C NMR (δ, ppm): 168 (C=O), 155 (C-O), 140–120 (8 aromatic C), 68 (OCH₂CO), 58 (CH₂SO₂), 52 (CH₂OH).
HSQC: Correlations between 4.8 ppm (¹H) and 68 ppm (¹³C), 3.8 ppm (¹H) and 58 ppm (¹³C), 3.6 ppm (¹H) and 52 ppm (¹³C).
solution:
Step 1: Calculate degrees of unsaturation.
(2C + 2 - H - X + N)/2 = (32 + 2 - 15 - 2 + 1)/2 = 9. Indicates 4 aromatic rings (8) + 1 carbonyl (1).

Step 2: Analyze IR data.
- 3300 cm⁻¹ (broad): O-H and N-H stretching (alcohol and amide).
- 1650 cm⁻¹ (sharp): Amide C=O.
- 1350/1150 cm⁻¹ (strong): Sulfone (SO₂) asymmetric/symmetric stretches.
- 1250 cm⁻¹ (medium): C-O ether stretch.
- 1600 cm⁻¹ (medium): Aromatic C=C.

Step 3: Mass spectrum interpretation.
- 403 (M⁺, 1:1 doublet): Molecular ion with two Cl isotopes (³⁵Cl/³⁷Cl).
- 368 (M−35): Loss of Cl atom.
- 339 (M−64): Loss of SO₂ group (64 Da).

Step 4: Analyze ¹H NMR.
- 8.2 ppm (s, 1H): Amide NH (desheilded by carbonyl).
- 7.6–7.4 ppm (m, 4H) and 7.2–7.0 ppm (m, 3H): Two aromatic rings (one with two Cl substituents causing downfield shifts, another with electron-withdrawing SO₂).
- 4.8 ppm (s, 2H): OCH₂CO (singlet, no adjacent protons).
- 3.8 ppm (t, 2H) and 3.6 ppm (t, 2H): CH₂SO₂ and CH₂OH (coupled to each other, J=6.5 Hz).
- 2.2 ppm (br s, 1H): Hydroxyl proton (broad due to hydrogen bonding).

Step 5: Analyze ¹³C NMR and HSQC.
- 168 ppm: Amide carbonyl.
- 155 ppm: Ether carbon (OCH₂CO).
- 140–120 ppm: 8 aromatic carbons (two substituted rings).
- 68 ppm: OCH₂CO (HSQC confirms correlation with 4.8 ppm proton).
- 58 ppm: CH₂SO₂ (HSQC confirms correlation with 3.8 ppm proton).
- 52 ppm: CH₂OH (HSQC confirms correlation with 3.6 ppm proton).

Step 6: Assemble the structure.
- Amide linkage: NH (8.2 ppm) and C=O (168 ppm) connect two aromatic rings.
- Left aromatic ring: Dichlorinated (two Cl from formula and 4 aromatic protons in 7.6–7.4 ppm).
- Right aromatic ring: Substituted with SO₂CH₂CH₂OH (sulfone IR peaks, CH₂ triplets in NMR).
- Ether linkage: OCH₂CO (4.8 ppm, 68 ppm) connects to the dichlorinated ring.

Final structure: O=C(COc1ccc(Cl)cc1Cl)Nc1cccc(S(=O)(=O)CCO)c1.

question:
A compound with molecular formula C₁₂H₁₇NO₆ exhibits the following spectroscopic data:

**IR (cm⁻¹):** 3320 (broad), 1725 (sharp), 1705 (sharp), 1650 (medium), 1250 (strong)
**Mass Spectrum (m/z):** 271 [M⁺], 228 [M⁺−43], 156 [M⁺−115]
**¹H NMR (δ, ppm):** 1.95 (s, 3H), 3.35 (q, J=6 Hz, 2H), 3.65 (t, J=6 Hz, 2H), 4.25 (t, J=6 Hz, 2H), 4.35 (t, J=6 Hz, 2H), 5.55 (dd, J=10, 2 Hz, 1H), 6.15 (dd, J=17, 2 Hz, 1H), 6.35 (dd, J=17, 10 Hz, 1H), 5.8 (broad s, 1H)
**¹³C NMR (δ, ppm):** 18.5, 40.5, 62.0, 64.5, 66.0, 125.5, 130.5, 137.0, 156.0, 165.5, 168.0
**HSQC:** Correlations between ¹H and ¹³C signals confirm direct H-C bonds.

Using the provided data, determine the structure of the compound and explain your reasoning.
solution:
Step 1: Analyze IR spectrum
- 3320 cm⁻¹ (broad): N-H stretch (carbamate or amide)
- 1725 and 1705 cm⁻¹ (sharp): Two distinct carbonyl groups (ester and carbamate)
- 1650 cm⁻¹: C=C stretch (alkene)
- 1250 cm⁻¹: C-O stretch (ester or ether)

Step 2: Interpret mass spectrum
- Molecular ion at m/z 271 matches C₁₂H₁₇NO₆ (MW=271)
- Fragment at 228 (loss of 43): Likely CH₂CH₂O (44-1) from ester cleavage
- Fragment at 156 (loss of 115): Suggests elimination of acryloyl-ethyleneglycol chain

Step 3: Analyze ¹H NMR
- 1.95 ppm (s, 3H): Methyl group adjacent to alkene (C=C-CH₃)
- 3.35 ppm (q, 2H) and 3.65 ppm (t, 2H): Ethylene glycol chain (OCH₂CH₂N)
- 4.25 and 4.35 ppm (t, 2H each): Ester-linked CH₂ groups
- 5.55-6.35 ppm (dd, 3H): Vinyl protons (CH₂=CH- and CH₂=C(CH₃)-)
- 5.8 ppm (broad): N-H proton (carbamate)

Step 4: Analyze ¹³C NMR
- 168.0 and 165.5 ppm: Ester carbonyls
- 156.0 ppm: Carbamate carbonyl (lower frequency than esters)
- 137.0 ppm: Quaternary alkene carbon (C=C(CH₃))
- 130.5 and 125.5 ppm: Vinyl carbons
- 18.5 ppm: Methyl group
- 40.5-66.0 ppm: Aliphatic CH₂ groups

Step 5: Combine HSQC correlations
- Confirms H-C bonds in CH₂ (4.25 ppm/64.5 ppm) and CH₃ (1.95 ppm/18.5 ppm)
- Links vinyl protons (5.55-6.35 ppm) to their respective carbons

Step 6: Assemble structure
- Molecular formula and spectral data indicate two ester groups, one carbamate, and two alkenes
- N-H at 3320 cm⁻¹ and 156 ppm carbonyl confirm carbamate linkage
- Vinyl signals and methyl group suggest acrylate (CH₂=CH-COO-) and methacrylate (CH₂=C(CH₃)-COO-) groups
- Ethylene glycol chains connect functional groups

Final structure: CH₂=CH-COO-CH₂CH₂-OCONH-CH₂CH₂-OOC-CH₂-C(CH₃)=CH₂ (SMILES: C=CC(=O)OCCOC(=O)NCCOC(=O)C(=C)C)

question:
Given the molecular formula C₁₇H₁₃BrN₂O₂ and the following spectral data, deduce the molecular structure. Provide evidence from each spectrum to support your conclusion.

**IR Spectrum**: Strong absorption at 1710 cm⁻¹, medium peaks at 1600 cm⁻¹ and 1250 cm⁻¹, no broad O-H or N-H stretches.

**Mass Spectrum**: Molecular ion peak at m/z 357/359 (1:1 ratio), base peak at m/z 298.

**¹H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl₃)**: δ 8.25 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H), 7.95 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.60–7.45 (m, 4H), 7.35–7.20 (m, 5H), 3.85 (s, 3H).

**¹³C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl₃)**: δ 155.2, 148.7, 142.3, 138.1, 132.5, 130.8, 129.4, 128.9, 127.7, 126.3, 123.1, 121.5, 120.7, 119.8, 117.4, 55.6.

**HSQC Spectrum**: Correlations between δ 3.85 (¹H) and δ 55.6 (¹³C); δ 8.25 (¹H) and δ 148.7 (¹³C); δ 7.95 (¹H) and δ 132.5 (¹³C).
solution:
Step 1: **Molecular Formula Analysis**
- Calculate degrees of unsaturation: (2C + 2 - H - X + N)/2 = (34 + 2 - 13 - 1 + 2)/2 = 12. This indicates multiple rings/π-bonds.

Step 2: **IR Spectrum Interpretation**
- 1710 cm⁻¹: Carbonyl (C=O) of a carbamate or ester.
- 1600 cm⁻¹: Aromatic C=C stretching.
- 1250 cm⁻¹: C-O stretching (consistent with a carbamate).
- Absence of O-H/N-H rules out alcohols, carboxylic acids, or amines.

Step 3: **Mass Spectrum Analysis**
- Molecular ion at m/z 357/359 (1:1 ratio): Confirms presence of bromine (⁷⁹Br and ⁸¹Br isotopes).
- Base peak at m/z 298: Loss of 59 Da (COOCH₃ fragment), characteristic of carbamate cleavage.

Step 4: **¹H NMR Analysis**
- δ 3.85 (s, 3H): Methoxy group (OCH₃) attached to a carbonyl (carbamate).
- Aromatic region (7.2–8.25 ppm, 10H): Two substituted aromatic systems. The doublets (J ≈ 8 Hz) suggest para-substituted benzene and a quinoline ring.

Step 5: **¹³C NMR and HSQC Analysis**
- δ 155.2: Carbamate carbonyl (C=O).
- δ 55.6: Methoxy carbon (correlates with δ 3.85 in HSQC).
- δ 148.7 and 132.5: Quaternary carbons adjacent to nitrogen and bromine (HSQC confirms protonated carbons at these positions).
- Aromatic carbons (117–142 ppm): Two benzene rings, one with bromine substitution (electron-withdrawing shifts carbons downfield).

Step 6: **Structure Assembly**
- Carbamate group: COOCH₃ (IR, MS, NMR).
- Bromine: Confirmed by MS isotope pattern and downfield shifts in NMR.
- Two aromatic systems: A phenyl group (δ 7.2–7.4, 5H) and a brominated quinoline (δ 7.6–8.25, 5H with coupling patterns).
- HSQC links protons to carbons, confirming substitution patterns (e.g., quinoline C-2 and C-8 protons).

**Final Structure**: Methyl N-phenyl-N-(8-bromoquinolin-2-yl)carbamate (SMILES: COC(=O)N(c1ccccc1)c1ccc2cccc(Br)c2n1).

question:
A compound with molecular formula C20H17Cl2NO3 exhibits the following spectroscopic data:

**IR (cm⁻¹):** 1735 (s), 1655 (m), 1580 (m), 1250 (s), 760 (s)
**Mass Spectrum (m/z):** 390 (M⁺, 100%), 345 (M⁺-C2H5O), 215 (M⁺-C7H3Cl2O), 175 (C7H3Cl2O⁺)
**¹H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz):** δ 7.85 (d, J=8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.60-7.30 (m, 6H), 7.15 (t, J=7.5 Hz, 1H), 4.20 (q, J=7.0 Hz, 2H), 3.75 (s, 2H), 2.45 (s, 3H), 1.25 (t, J=7.0 Hz, 3H)
**¹³C NMR (CDCl3, 100 MHz):** δ 170.2, 165.8, 140.5, 135.0, 132.5, 131.0 (2C), 130.5 (2C), 129.8, 129.5, 128.0, 127.5, 126.0, 124.5, 123.0, 110.0, 61.0, 35.5, 14.0, 12.0
**HSQC:** Correlations observed between δ 4.20 (¹H) ↔ 61.0 (¹³C), 3.75 (¹H) ↔ 35.5 (¹³C), 1.25 (¹H) ↔ 14.0 (¹³C), 2.45 (¹H) ↔ 12.0 (¹³C).

Determine the molecular structure and explain how each spectral feature supports your conclusion.
solution:
Step 1: **Molecular Formula Analysis**
C20H17Cl2NO3 gives a degree of unsaturation = (2×20 + 2 - 17 - 2)/2 = 12.5 → 12 rings/π-bonds. This suggests multiple aromatic rings and/or carbonyl groups.

Step 2: **IR Interpretation**
- 1735 cm⁻¹: Ester C=O stretch
- 1655 cm⁻¹: Amide C=O stretch (lower than typical ketone due to resonance)
- 1580 cm⁻¹: Aromatic C=C
- 1250 cm⁻¹: C-O stretch (ester)
- 760 cm⁻¹: C-Cl stretch (aromatic)

Step 3: **Mass Spectrum**
- M⁺ = 390 matches molecular formula
- Key fragments:
  - 345 (M⁺ - C2H5O): Loss of ethoxy group from ester
  - 215 (M⁺ - C7H3Cl2O): Loss of 2,6-dichlorobenzoyl group
  - 175 (C7H3Cl2O⁺): 2,6-dichlorobenzoyl cation (base peak)

Step 4: **¹H NMR Analysis**
- 4.20 (q, 2H) & 1.25 (t, 3H): Ethyl ester group (OCH2CH3)
- 3.75 (s, 2H): Methylene adjacent to ester (CH2COOEt)
- 2.45 (s, 3H): Methyl group on aromatic ring
- 7.85 (d, 1H) & 7.60-7.30 (m, 6H) & 7.15 (t, 1H): 7 aromatic protons (2,6-dichlorophenyl + indole ring)

Step 5: **¹³C NMR and HSQC**
- 170.2 (ester C=O), 165.8 (amide C=O)
- 61.0 (OCH2CH3) and 14.0 (OCH2CH3) confirmed by HSQC
- 35.5 (CH2COOEt) and 12.0 (CH3) confirmed by HSQC
- 131.0 (2C) and 130.5 (2C): Symmetrical dichlorophenyl carbons

Step 6: **Structure Assembly**
- Ethyl ester (from IR, NMR) and 2,6-dichlorobenzoyl group (from MS, aromatic pattern)
- Indole core (9H-indole derivative with 7 aromatic protons)
- Methyl at position 2 and CH2COOEt at position 3 (NMR splitting patterns)
- Amide carbonyl at position 1 (from IR and MS fragmentation)

Final Structure: Ethyl 2-(2-methyl-1-(2,6-dichlorobenzoyl)-1H-indol-3-yl)acetate

This structure satisfies all spectral data and molecular formula constraints.

question:
Given the molecular formula C₁₉H₂₁N₃O₂ and the following spectral data, determine the molecular structure:

IR (cm⁻¹): 1715 (strong, sharp), 3050 (medium), 1250 (strong)
Mass Spectrum: m/z 323 (M⁺, 100%), 308 (M-15, base peak), 165 (key fragment)

¹H NMR (CDCl₃, 400 MHz): δ 1.40 (t, 3H, J=7.2 Hz), 2.45 (s, 3H), 2.55 (s, 3H), 3.95 (s, 3H), 4.15 (q, 2H, J=7.2 Hz), 5.40 (s, 2H), 7.25 (d, 2H, J=8.4 Hz), 7.35 (s, 1H), 7.90 (d, 2H, J=8.4 Hz), 8.05 (s, 1H)

¹³C NMR (CDCl₃, 100 MHz): δ 14.2, 21.1, 22.3, 45.8, 52.1, 112.5, 120.8, 123.7, 127.9, 128.5, 130.2, 135.6, 138.4, 142.7, 148.9, 152.3, 155.7, 166.3

HSQC: Correlations observed between:
- 1.40 ppm (3H) and 14.2 ppm
- 4.15 ppm (2H) and 45.8 ppm
- 5.40 ppm (2H) and 52.1 ppm
- 3.95 ppm (3H) and 52.1 ppm
- 2.45 ppm (3H) and 21.1 ppm
- 2.55 ppm (3H) and 22.3 ppm
- 7.25 ppm (2H) and 127.9 ppm
- 7.90 ppm (2H) and 130.2 ppm
- 7.35 ppm (1H) and 123.7 ppm
- 8.05 ppm (1H) and 142.7 ppm
solution:
Step 1: Analyze molecular formula and degrees of unsaturation
C₁₉H₂₁N₃O₂ → 19 carbons, 21 hydrogens, 3 nitrogens, 2 oxygens
Degrees of unsaturation = (2C + 2 - H + N)/2 = (38 + 2 - 21 + 3)/2 = 11
Suggests multiple rings/π bonds (e.g., aromatic systems).

Step 2: Interpret IR data
- 1715 cm⁻¹: Ester carbonyl (C=O)
- 3050 cm⁻¹: Aromatic C-H stretching
- 1250 cm⁻¹: C-O stretching (ester)

Step 3: Mass spectrometry analysis
- M⁺ = 323 (matches formula)
- M-15 (308): Loss of CH₃• (common for methyl esters)
- Base peak at 165: Suggests stable aromatic fragment (benzimidazole core)

Step 4: ¹H NMR analysis
- 1.40 t (3H) & 4.15 q (2H): Ethyl group (CH₂CH₃, J=7.2 Hz)
- 2.45 s (3H) & 2.55 s (3H): Two aromatic methyl groups
- 3.95 s (3H): Methoxy group (OCH₃)
- 5.40 s (2H): Benzylic CH₂ (N-CH₂-Ar)
- 7.25 d (2H) & 7.90 d (2H): Para-substituted benzene ring
- 7.35 s (1H) & 8.05 s (1H): Aromatic protons on benzimidazole

Step 5: ¹³C NMR and HSQC correlation
- 14.2 ppm (CH₃) & 45.8 ppm (CH₂): Ethyl group
- 21.1 ppm & 22.3 ppm: Aromatic methyl carbons
- 52.1 ppm (OCH₃) & 166.3 ppm (ester C=O)
- 127.9 ppm & 130.2 ppm: Para-substituted benzene carbons
- 112.5 ppm, 123.7 ppm, 142.7 ppm: Benzimidazole ring carbons

Step 6: Assemble structural fragments
- Ester group: COOCH₃ (IR, ¹H/¹³C NMR, MS)
- Benzimidazole core: Two singlet aromatic protons (7.35, 8.05 ppm), 11 carbons in aromatic region
- Ethyl group: Attached to benzimidazole nitrogen (HSQC, chemical shift)
- Para-substituted benzene: Connected via benzylic CH₂ (5.40 ppm)
- Two methyl groups: On benzimidazole aromatic ring

Step 7: Final structure determination
Combining all data: The compound is a benzimidazole derivative with:
- N1-ethyl substituent
- N3-(4-methoxycarbonylbenzyl) group
- 5,6-dimethyl substitution on benzimidazole ring
This matches the SMILES: CCc1nc2c(C)cc(C)nc2n1Cc1ccc(C(=O)OC)cc1

question:
A compound with molecular formula C19H20BrN3O4S exhibits the following spectroscopic data:

- **IR (cm⁻¹)**: 3300 (broad), 1680, 1320, 1160
- **Mass Spectrum (m/z)**: 466 (M⁺, 100%), 468 (M⁺+2, 98%), 397, 399
- **¹H NMR (δ, ppm)**: 2.3 (s, 3H), 2.5 (s, 3H), 1.5–1.8 (m, 8H), 3.8 (m, 1H), 7.2 (d, J=8.5 Hz, 1H), 7.6 (d, J=8.5 Hz, 1H), 7.8 (s, 1H), 8.2 (s, 1H), 10.8 (br s, 1H), 12.1 (br s, 1H)
- **¹³C NMR (δ, ppm)**: 12, 14, 25, 30, 48, 110, 115, 120, 125, 130, 135, 140, 150, 160, 165, 170
- **HSQC**: Correlations observed between: 2.3 ppm (¹H) ↔ 12 ppm (¹³C), 2.5 ppm (¹H) ↔ 14 ppm (¹³C), 3.8 ppm (¹H) ↔ 48 ppm (¹³C), and aromatic protons (7.2–8.2 ppm) ↔ 110–160 ppm (¹³C).

Using all data, determine the structure and explain key assignments.
solution:
Step 1: **Mass Spectrum Analysis**
The molecular ion at m/z 466 (M⁺) matches the molecular formula C19H20BrN3O4S (MW = 466 g/mol). The M⁺+2 peak at 468 with ~1:1 intensity ratio confirms a bromine atom. Fragment peaks at 397 and 399 (M⁺ – 69) suggest loss of a C5H9 group (cyclopentyl).

Step 2: **IR Spectrum Interpretation**
- 3300 cm⁻¹ (broad): N–H stretches (sulfonamide and pyridone).
- 1680 cm⁻¹: C=O stretch (pyridone carbonyl).
- 1320 and 1160 cm⁻¹: S=O stretches (sulfonamide).

Step 3: **¹H NMR Analysis**
- 2.3 and 2.5 ppm (singlets, 3H each): Methyl groups on isoxazole ring.
- 1.5–1.8 ppm (multiplets, 8H): Cyclopentyl CH₂ groups.
- 3.8 ppm (multiplet, 1H): Cyclopentyl CH (attached to N).
- 7.2 ppm (d, J=8.5 Hz, 1H) and 7.6 ppm (d, J=8.5 Hz, 1H): Aromatic protons on benzene ring (ortho-coupled).
- 7.8 ppm (s, 1H) and 8.2 ppm (s, 1H): Aromatic protons on isoxazole and pyridone rings.
- 10.8 ppm (br s, 1H): Sulfonamide N–H.
- 12.1 ppm (br s, 1H): Pyridone N–H.

Step 4: **¹³C NMR and HSQC Correlations**
- 12 and 14 ppm: Methyl carbons (HSQC confirms correlation with 2.3 and 2.5 ppm protons).
- 25, 30, 48 ppm: Cyclopentyl carbons (HSQC links 48 ppm to 3.8 ppm proton).
- 110–160 ppm: Aromatic carbons (HSQC correlates with aromatic protons).
- 170 ppm: Pyridone carbonyl carbon.

Step 5: **Degrees of Unsaturation**
Calculated as 11 (from formula), consistent with: isoxazole (2), benzene (4), pyridone (2), and three rings total.

Step 6: **Structure Assembly**
- The isoxazole ring (methyls at 2.3 and 2.5 ppm) is linked to a brominated benzene ring (aromatic doublets at 7.2 and 7.6 ppm).
- The sulfonamide group (S=O IR, N–H at 10.8 ppm) connects to a cyclopentyl group (¹H and ¹³C data).
- The pyridone ring (carbonyl at 170 ppm, N–H at 12.1 ppm) is fused to the benzene ring, forming a quinolone core.
- Bromine is positioned ortho to the sulfonamide group (aromatic splitting pattern).

Final structure: 5-Bromo-3-(3,5-dimethylisoxazol-4-yl)-N-cyclopentyl-8-hydroxyquinoline-6-sulfonamide (SMILES: Cc1noc(C)c1-c1cc(S(=O)(=O)NC2CCCC2)c2cc(Br)c(=O)[nH]c2c1).

question:
A compound with molecular formula C28H42O4S exhibits the following spectral data. Use the provided IR, mass spectrometry, ¹H NMR, ¹³C NMR, and HSQC data to deduce its structure. Explain your reasoning.

**IR (cm⁻¹):** 3350 (broad), 1600, 1500, 1250, 1040
**Mass Spec (m/z):** 490 [M+H]⁺, 434 [M−C₄H₉]⁺, 273 [M−C₁₄H₂₁O₃S]⁺
**¹H NMR (δ ppm):** 7.15 (d, J=8.0 Hz, 2H), 7.05 (d, J=8.0 Hz, 2H), 6.95 (d, J=8.0 Hz, 2H), 6.85 (d, J=8.0 Hz, 2H), 3.90-3.80 (m, 3H), 3.60-3.50 (m, 4H), 2.85 (t, J=7.0 Hz, 2H), 2.55 (q, J=7.5 Hz, 4H), 1.90 (s, 3H), 1.85 (s, 3H), 1.35 (t, J=7.5 Hz, 6H), 1.25 (s, 9H)
**¹³C NMR (δ ppm):** 145.2, 144.8, 135.1, 134.9, 129.5, 129.3, 127.8, 127.5, 74.5, 69.2, 64.1, 55.3, 48.6, 37.8, 31.5, 31.2, 28.9, 23.4, 14.2
**HSQC:** Correlations between 7.15 ppm (H) and 129.5 ppm (C), 3.90 ppm (H) and 74.5 ppm (C), 2.85 ppm (H) and 55.3 ppm (C), 1.25 ppm (H) and 28.9 ppm (C).
solution:
### Step-by-Step Analysis:

1. **Molecular Formula & Degrees of Unsaturation:**
   - C₂₈H₄₂O₄S: Calculate degrees of unsaturation = (2C + 2 − H)/2 = (56 + 2 − 42)/2 = 8. Suggests 4 rings + 4 double bonds (or equivalents).

2. **IR Spectrum:**
   - **3350 cm⁻¹ (broad):** O−H stretch (diol group).
   - **1600, 1500 cm⁻¹:** Aromatic C=C.
   - **1250 cm⁻¹:** C−O stretch (ether/hydroxyl).
   - **1040 cm⁻¹:** S=O stretch (sulfoxide).

3. **Mass Spectrometry:**
   - **m/z 490 [M+H]⁺:** Confirms molecular weight (C₂₈H₄₂O₄S, MW = 490.7 g/mol).
   - **Fragment at 434:** Loss of tert-butyl (C₄H₉, 56 Da), indicating a tert-butyl group attached to S.
   - **Fragment at 273:** Cleavage adjacent to sulfoxide, retaining the S-containing fragment.

4. **¹H NMR Analysis:**
   - **Aromatic Region (7.15−6.85 ppm, 8H):** Two sets of para-substituted benzene rings (each with 2H doublets, J=8.0 Hz).
   - **3.90−3.50 ppm (7H):** 
     - 3.90−3.80 ppm (m, 3H): Methine proton (CHO) and two CH₂O protons (diol + ether).
     - 3.60−3.50 ppm (m, 4H): Two CH₂ groups adjacent to oxygen (OCH₂ and CH₂OH).
   - **2.85 ppm (t, 2H):** CH₂ adjacent to sulfoxide (S−CH₂, deshielded by S=O).
   - **2.55 ppm (q, 4H) & 1.35 ppm (t, 6H):** Two ethyl groups (CH₂CH₃, J=7.5 Hz).
   - **1.90 & 1.85 ppm (s, 3H each):** Two aromatic methyl groups.
   - **1.25 ppm (s, 9H):** tert-Butyl group (C(CH₃)₃).

5. **¹³C NMR & HSQC:**
   - **Aromatic Carbons:** 145.2, 144.8 (quaternary), 129.5, 129.3, 127.8, 127.5 (CH, para-substituted rings).
   - **Oxygenated Carbons:** 74.5 (CH, diol), 69.2 (CH₂, ether), 64.1 (CH₂, diol).
   - **Sulfoxide-Adjacent Carbon:** 55.3 (CH₂, S−CH₂).
   - **Quaternary Carbon:** 48.6 (central carbon bonded to two ethyls and two rings).
   - **Alkyl Carbons:** 37.8 (CH₂, ethyl), 31.5, 31.2 (methyls), 28.9 (tert-butyl), 23.4 (ethyl CH₂), 14.2 (ethyl CH₃).

6. **Structure Assembly:**
   - **Core Structure:** A quaternary carbon (48.6 ppm) bonded to two ethyl groups (CH₂CH₃), two para-substituted benzene rings, and no hydrogens (consistent with ¹H NMR).
   - **Aromatic Substituents:**
     - **Ring 1:** Methyl (1.90 ppm) and −CH₂S(O)C(CH₃)₃ (2.85 ppm CH₂, 1.25 ppm tert-butyl).
     - **Ring 2:** Methyl (1.85 ppm) and −OCH₂CH(OH)CH₂OH (3.90−3.50 ppm, diol + ether).
   - **Sulfoxide Group:** Confirmed by IR (1040 cm⁻¹) and S−CH₂ signal (55.3 ppm).

**Final Structure:**
CCC(CC)(c1ccc(CCS(=O)C(C)(C)C)c(C)c1)c1ccc(OC[C@@H](O)CO)c(C)c1

question:
Given the molecular formula C₂₀H₂₈N₂O₂S and the following spectral data, deduce the molecular structure and explain how each spectral feature supports your conclusion:

1. **IR Spectrum**: Strong absorption at 1335 cm⁻¹ and 1160 cm⁻¹; broad peak at 3350 cm⁻¹; aromatic C-H stretches at 3050 cm⁻¹.
2. **Mass Spectrum**: Molecular ion peak at m/z 360; major fragment at m/z 303.
3. **¹H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl₃)**: δ 7.75 (d, J=8.4 Hz, 2H), 7.30 (d, J=8.4 Hz, 2H), 6.95 (d, J=8.2 Hz, 2H), 6.65 (d, J=8.2 Hz, 2H), 4.00 (br s, 2H), 3.20 (t, J=7.2 Hz, 2H), 2.85 (t, J=7.2 Hz, 2H), 2.40 (s, 3H), 1.95-1.85 (m, 1H), 1.50-1.40 (m, 2H), 0.95 (d, J=6.6 Hz, 6H).
4. **¹³C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl₃)**: δ 143.2, 140.5, 137.8, 135.1, 129.8, 127.6, 127.2, 116.3, 52.1, 49.8, 35.7, 28.9, 25.4, 21.3, 20.7.
5. **HSQC Spectrum**: Correlations between δ 3.20 (¹H) and δ 52.1 (¹³C); δ 2.85 (¹H) and δ 49.8 (¹³C); δ 0.95 (¹H) and δ 20.7 (¹³C).
solution:
Step-by-step analysis:

1. **Degrees of Unsaturation**: C₂₀H₂₈N₂O₂S → (2×20 + 2 - 28 + 2)/2 = 8. Suggests two aromatic rings (4 each).

2. **IR Interpretation**:
   - 1335 & 1160 cm⁻¹: Sulfone (S=O) stretches, diagnostic of sulfonamide.
   - 3350 cm⁻¹: Broad N-H stretch from primary aromatic amine (-NH₂).
   - 3050 cm⁻¹: Aromatic C-H vibrations.

3. **Mass Spectrum**:
   - M⁺ at 360: Matches molecular weight (C₂₀H₂₈N₂O₂S = 360.5).
   - Fragment at 303: Loss of 57 Da (C₄H₉, isobutyl group), indicating cleavage at the sulfonamide N-alkyl bond.

4. **¹H NMR Analysis**:
   - δ 7.75 (d, 2H) & 7.30 (d, 2H): Para-substituted benzene ring (tosyl group).
   - δ 6.95 (d, 2H) & 6.65 (d, 2H): Para-substituted aniline ring (-NH₂ at para position).
   - δ 4.00 (br s, 2H): Primary amine (-NH₂) protons.
   - δ 3.20 (t, 2H) & 2.85 (t, 2H): Ethylene bridge (-CH₂CH₂-) between sulfonamide N and aniline ring.
   - δ 2.40 (s, 3H): Tosyl methyl group (-C₆H₄-SO₂-CH₃).
   - δ 1.95-1.85 (m, 1H) & 0.95 (d, 6H): Isobutyl group (-CH(CH₃)₂).
   - δ 1.50-1.40 (m, 2H): Methylene in isobutyl chain.

5. **¹³C NMR & HSQC**:
   - δ 143.2, 140.5, 137.8, 135.1: Quaternary aromatic carbons (tosyl and aniline rings).
   - δ 129.8, 127.6, 127.2, 116.3: Protonated aromatic carbons (HSQC confirms H-C pairs).
   - δ 52.1 & 49.8: N-CH₂ groups (HSQC links to δ 3.20 and 2.85 in ¹H NMR).
   - δ 35.7: Isobutyl methine carbon (-CH(CH₃)₂).
   - δ 25.4 & 20.7: Isobutyl methyl carbons (HSQC links to δ 0.95).
   - δ 21.3: Tosyl methyl carbon.

6. **Structure Assembly**:
   - Sulfonamide core (-SO₂-N-) confirmed by IR and NMR.
   - Tosyl group (p-methylbenzenesulfonyl) attached to N.
   - N-ethyl linker to para-aminophenyl ring (HSQC confirms -CH₂CH₂-).
   - N-isobutyl substituent (fragmentation and NMR data).

**Final Structure**: p-Methyl-N-(2-(4-aminophenyl)ethyl)-N-isobutylbenzenesulfonamide (SMILES: Cc1ccc(S(=O)(=O)N(CCc2ccc(N)cc2)CCC(C)C)cc1).

question:
A compound with molecular formula C₂₇H₂₈N₆O exhibits the following spectral data:

IR (cm⁻¹): 3380 (broad), 1655 (sharp), 1590, 1495, 1250
Mass Spectrum: m/z 452 [M⁺], 323 [M⁺-C₉H₁₁N₂O], 267 [M⁺-C₁₄H₁₆N₃O]
¹H NMR (δ, ppm): 8.85 (d, J=5.2 Hz, 1H), 8.32 (s, 1H), 8.15 (d, J=8.4 Hz, 1H), 7.92 (d, J=8.4 Hz, 1H), 7.78 (dd, J=8.4, 2.0 Hz, 1H), 7.65 (d, J=5.2 Hz, 1H), 7.35 (s, 1H), 4.50 (m, 1H), 3.85-3.65 (m, 4H), 3.20-3.00 (m, 4H), 2.85 (br s, 2H), 1.20-0.80 (m, 4H), 0.65-0.45 (m, 4H)
¹³C NMR (δ, ppm): 172.3, 158.1, 155.2, 150.4, 148.7, 142.6, 138.5, 135.4, 129.8, 127.9, 123.1, 121.7, 119.3, 115.6, 58.2, 47.6, 45.3, 42.1, 32.8, 28.5, 26.4, 24.7, 12.3, 10.8
HSQC: Correlations between 4.50 ppm (¹H) and 58.2 ppm (¹³C), 3.85-3.65 ppm (¹H) and 45.3 ppm (¹³C), 0.65-0.45 ppm (¹H) and 10.8 ppm (¹³C)

Determine the molecular structure and explain how each spectral feature supports your conclusion.
solution:
Step 1: Calculate degrees of unsaturation.
(2C + 2 + N - H)/2 = (2×27 + 2 + 6 - 28)/2 = 15. This indicates multiple rings/π bonds.

Step 2: Analyze IR data.
- 3380 cm⁻¹ (broad): N-H stretch (amine)
- 1655 cm⁻¹ (sharp): Amide C=O
- 1590/1495 cm⁻¹: Aromatic C=C
- 1250 cm⁻¹: C-N stretch

Step 3: Mass spectrum interpretation.
- M⁺ = 452 matches molecular formula
- Fragment 323: Loss of C₉H₁₁N₂O (piperidine + amide group)
- Fragment 267: Loss of C₁₄H₁₆N₃O (pyrimidine + pyridine + cyclopropane)

Step 4: ¹H NMR analysis.
- 8.85-7.35 ppm (7H): Aromatic protons (pyridine, pyrimidine, benzene)
- 4.50 ppm (m, 1H): Methine proton adjacent to N (piperidine)
- 3.85-3.00 ppm (8H): Piperidine CH₂ and N-CH₂ groups
- 2.85 ppm (br s, 2H): Primary amine NH₂
- 1.20-0.45 ppm (8H): Cyclopropane protons (two distinct environments)

Step 5: ¹³C NMR and HSQC correlations.
- 172.3 ppm: Amide carbonyl
- 158.1-115.6 ppm: 12 aromatic carbons
- 58.2 ppm: Methine carbon (HSQC to 4.50 ppm)
- 45.3 ppm: N-CH₂ (HSQC to 3.85-3.65 ppm)
- 10.8 ppm: Cyclopropane carbon (HSQC to 0.65-0.45 ppm)

Step 6: Assemble structural fragments.
- Amide group (IR + ¹³C NMR) connects piperidine and benzene
- Cyclopropane (NMR shifts + HSQC) attached to pyridine
- Spirocyclic cyclopropane (¹³C NMR quaternary carbons at 32.8/28.5 ppm)
- Primary amine on piperidine (IR + ¹H NMR)
- Pyrimidine-pyridine system (aromatic coupling patterns)

Step 7: Final structure verification.
All spectral features match the given SMILES:
N[C@@H]1CCN(C(=O)c2ccc3c(c2)N(c2ncc(-c4cc(C5CC5)ccn4)cn2)CC32CC2)C1

question:
A compound with molecular formula C29H25N3O2 exhibits the following spectroscopic data:

IR (cm⁻¹): 3320 (broad), 1705 (sharp), 1655 (sharp), 1600, 1540, 1450.
Mass Spectrum: m/z 447 (M⁺, 100%), 369 (base peak), 105 (significant fragment).
¹H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ 2.35 (s, 3H), 3.25 (t, J=7.2 Hz, 2H), 3.60 (t, J=7.2 Hz, 2H), 6.80-6.95 (m, 3H), 7.10-7.30 (m, 8H), 7.40-7.50 (m, 2H), 7.65 (d, J=8.4 Hz, 2H), 8.55 (s, 1H, exchangeable with D2O).
¹³C NMR (CDCl3, 100 MHz): δ 21.2, 24.5, 43.8, 109.3, 115.6, 119.8, 120.1, 123.4, 126.7, 127.2, 128.1, 128.5, 129.3, 130.2, 135.6, 137.4, 139.1, 141.2, 142.7, 154.3, 168.9, 196.1.
HSQC: Correlations observed between δH 2.35/δC 21.2, δH 3.25/δC 24.5, δH 3.60/δC 43.8, and aromatic proton-carbon pairs matching substitution pattern.

Analyze all spectra systematically and confirm the structure matches the provided SMILES: Cc1ccc(-c2ccccc2C(=O)Nc2ccc3c(c2)CCN3C(=O)Cc2ccccn2)cc1.
solution:
Step 1: IR Analysis
- 3320 cm⁻¹ (broad): N-H stretch (amide).
- 1705 cm⁻¹ (sharp): Ketone C=O (indole N-acyl group).
- 1655 cm⁻¹ (sharp): Amide C=O.
- 1600/1540/1450 cm⁻¹: Aromatic C=C stretches.

Step 2: Mass Spectrum
- M⁺ = 447: Confirms molecular formula C29H25N3O2 (calculated mass: 447.53).
- m/z 369 (base peak): Loss of pyridinylmethyl group (C6H4N, 78 Da) from M⁺.
- m/z 105: Benzoyl fragment (C6H5CO⁺), diagnostic of benzamide derivatives.

Step 3: ¹H NMR Analysis
- δ 2.35 (s, 3H): Methyl group on para-substituted benzene ring.
- δ 3.25 (t, 2H) & 3.60 (t, 2H): Ethylene bridge (CH2-CH2) in indoline ring.
- δ 6.80-8.55 (complex aromatic signals): Multiple aromatic systems (benzene, pyridine, indole).
- δ 8.55 (s, exchangeable): Amide N-H (D2O exchange confirms).

Step 4: ¹³C NMR and HSQC
- δ 21.2: Methyl carbon (correlates with δH 2.35).
- δ 24.5 & 43.8: Ethylene bridge carbons (correlate with δH 3.25 and 3.60).
- δ 168.9: Amide carbonyl (C=O).
- δ 196.1: Ketone carbonyl (C=O).
- Aromatic carbons (109.3-154.3 ppm) match substitution pattern of indole, benzene, and pyridine rings.

Step 5: Structure Confirmation
- Combined data confirms: 
  (1) Benzamide moiety (IR 1655 cm⁻¹, m/z 105).
  (2) Indoline ring with ethylene bridge (¹H NMR doublet triplets, ¹³C 24.5/43.8).
  (3) N-acyl ketone (IR 1705 cm⁻¹, δC 196.1).
  (4) Pyridine ring (aromatic NMR pattern, m/z 369 loss).
All evidence matches the provided SMILES structure.

question:
A compound with molecular formula C22H15F6N3O4 yields the following spectral data:

**IR (cm⁻¹):** 3300-2500 (broad), 1720 (s), 1600 (m), 1250 (s), 1050 (s)
**Mass Spectrum (m/z):** 499 [M]+, 430 [M-CF3]+, 386 [M-CO2CF3]+
**¹H NMR (δ, ppm):** 1.65 (d, J=6.5 Hz, 3H), 4.20 (q, J=6.5 Hz, 1H), 5.20 (s, 2H), 7.25-7.80 (m, 7H), 8.20 (s, 1H), 10.80 (br s, 1H)
**¹³C NMR (δ, ppm):** 18.5 (CH3), 68.2 (CH), 69.8 (CH2), 115.0-135.0 (aromatic C), 145.0 (quaternary C), 158.0 (C=O), 162.0 (C=N), 170.5 (COOH)
**HSQC:** Correlations between 1.65 ppm (¹H) and 18.5 ppm (¹³C), 4.20 ppm (¹H) and 68.2 ppm (¹³C), 5.20 ppm (¹H) and 69.8 ppm (¹³C).

Determine the molecular structure and explain how each spectral feature supports your conclusion.
solution:
Step 1: **Molecular Formula Analysis**
- Degrees of Unsaturation (DoU): (2C + 2 - H - X + N)/2 = (44 + 2 - 15 - 6 + 3)/2 = 14. Indicates multiple rings/π bonds.
- Presence of 6F, 3N, and 4O suggests fluorinated aromatic system, nitrogen heterocycles, and oxygenated functional groups.

Step 2: **IR Interpretation**
- 3300-2500 cm⁻¹ (broad): O-H stretch of carboxylic acid.
- 1720 cm⁻¹: C=O stretch of carboxylic acid.
- 1250 cm⁻¹ and 1050 cm⁻¹: C-F and C-O stretches, respectively.
- 1600 cm⁻¹: Aromatic C=C or C=N stretching.

Step 3: **Mass Spectrometry**
- Molecular ion at m/z 499 matches C22H15F6N3O4.
- Fragment at 430 [M-CF3]+ confirms CF3 group loss.
- Fragment at 386 [M-CO2CF3]+ indicates carboxylic acid and CF3 loss.

Step 4: **¹H NMR Analysis**
- 1.65 ppm (d, 3H) and 4.20 ppm (q, 1H): Diastereotopic CH3 and CH of an O-CH(CH3)- group (J=6.5 Hz coupling).
- 5.20 ppm (s, 2H): CH2 group adjacent to electronegative atom (e.g., O or N).
- 7.25-7.80 ppm (m, 7H): Aromatic protons from multiple substituted rings.
- 8.20 ppm (s, 1H): Deshielded proton on nitrogen-containing heterocycle (e.g., pyrrole).
- 10.80 ppm (br s, 1H): Carboxylic acid proton.

Step 5: **¹³C NMR and HSQC**
- 18.5 ppm (CH3), 68.2 ppm (CH), 69.8 ppm (CH2): Confirmed by HSQC correlations.
- 158.0 ppm (C=O) and 170.5 ppm (COOH): Carbonyl carbons.
- 162.0 ppm (C=N): Oxadiazole or imine-type carbon.
- Aromatic carbons (115-135 ppm) and quaternary carbon (145 ppm) support substituted benzene rings.

Step 6: **Structure Assembly**
- Carboxylic acid (IR, ¹H, ¹³C) and CF3 groups (IR, MS, ¹³C) are confirmed.
- O-CH(CH3)- group (¹H, HSQC) links to an aromatic ring.
- CH2 (5.20 ppm) connects to a pyrrole NH (8.20 ppm) and COOH (10.80 ppm).
- 162.0 ppm (C=N) and 145 ppm (quaternary C) suggest a 1,2,4-oxadiazole ring.
- Aromatic substitution pattern matches two benzene rings (one with CF3, one with oxadiazole).

**Final Structure:** C[C@H](Oc1ccc(-c2nc(-c3cccc4c3ccn4CC(=O)O)no2)cc1C(F)(F)F)C(F)(F)F
- All spectral data align with this structure, including fluorine substituents, carboxylic acid, ether linkage, pyrrole, and oxadiazole ring.

question:
A compound with molecular formula C27H28N2O5 exhibits the following spectral data:

IR (cm⁻¹): 3200 (broad), 1685 (sharp), 1600, 1250
Mass Spectrum: m/z 460 [M+H]⁺
¹H NMR (δ, ppm): 10.1 (1H, s), 7.3-7.5 (5H, m), 6.9 (2H, s), 5.2 (2H, s), 4.1 (2H, t), 3.9 (3H, s), 3.7 (2H, t), 3.3 (3H, s), 2.3 (6H, s)
¹³C NMR (δ, ppm): 165, 158, 155, 150, 140, 137, 129, 128, 127, 115, 110, 71, 70, 69, 59, 55, 21
HSQC: Correlations observed between 4.1 ppm (2H) ↔ 71 ppm, 3.7 ppm (2H) ↔ 70 ppm, 3.3 ppm (3H) ↔ 59 ppm, and 5.2 ppm (2H) ↔ 69 ppm.

Determine the molecular structure and assign key spectral features to structural elements.
solution:
Step 1: Analyze molecular formula and IR data
- C27H28N2O5 indicates 14 degrees of unsaturation (rings + π-bonds). IR peaks at 1685 cm⁻¹ (C=O) and 3200 cm⁻¹ (broad N-H) suggest a secondary amide or lactam. The 1600 cm⁻¹ peak indicates aromatic C=C bonds.

Step 2: Confirm molecular weight
- Mass spec m/z 460 [M+H]⁺ matches calculated MW (460.52 g/mol), confirming the formula.

Step 3: Interpret ¹H NMR signals
- 10.1 ppm (s, 1H): Exchangeable proton from NH in a lactam ring
- 7.3-7.5 ppm (m, 5H): Monosubstituted benzene (benzyl group)
- 6.9 ppm (s, 2H): Aromatic protons on a symmetrically substituted ring
- 5.2 ppm (s, 2H): O-CH2-Ph (benzyl ether)
- 4.1 ppm (t, 2H) and 3.7 ppm (t, 2H): Ethylene glycol chain (OCH2CH2O)
- 3.9 ppm (s, 3H) and 3.3 ppm (s, 3H): Two distinct methoxy groups
- 2.3 ppm (s, 6H): Two aromatic methyl groups (likely para-substituted)

Step 4: Analyze ¹³C NMR and HSQC
- 165 ppm: Lactam carbonyl (C=O)
- 158, 155, 150 ppm: Oxygen-substituted aromatic carbons
- 140 ppm: Quaternary aromatic carbon (attachment point for aryl group)
- 71 ppm (HSQC to 4.1 ppm) and 70 ppm (HSQC to 3.7 ppm): Ethylene glycol carbons
- 69 ppm (HSQC to 5.2 ppm): Benzyl methylene carbon
- 59 ppm (HSQC to 3.3 ppm): Terminal methoxy carbon
- 55 ppm: Aromatic methoxy carbon
- 21 ppm: Aromatic methyl carbons

Step 5: Assemble structural fragments
- Lactam core (quinazolinone) from NH, C=O, and aromatic carbons
- Benzyl ether group (OCH2Ph) from 5.2 ppm and 69 ppm signals
- Ethylene glycol methyl ether (OCH2CH2OCH3) from triplet pattern and HSQC correlations
- Two aromatic methyl groups and methoxy substituents on a para-disubstituted benzene ring

Step 6: Combine fragments into final structure
The structure consists of a quinazolinone core with:
1. A benzyl-protected hydroxyl group at position 6
2. A methoxy group at position 8
3. A 2-methoxyethoxy substituent at position 2
4. A 3,5-dimethyl-4-benzyloxyphenyl group at position 4

This matches the provided SMILES: COCCOc1cc(OC)c2c(=O)[nH]c(-c3cc(C)c(OCc4ccccc4)c(C)c3)nc2c1

question:
A compound with molecular formula C₁₅H₁₅N₃O₂S₂ exhibits the following spectroscopic data:

IR (cm⁻¹): 2250 (sharp), 1345 (strong), 1155 (strong), 3300 (broad)
Mass Spectrum: Molecular ion at m/z 333, major fragment at m/z 286
¹H NMR (δ, ppm): 2.5 (s, 3H), 5.5 (d, J=8 Hz, 1H), 7.0 (br s, 2H), 7.2–7.8 (m, 8H)
¹³C NMR (δ, ppm): 15 (CH₃), 60 (CH), 115 (C), 125–140 (8 aromatic C), 150 (C)
HSQC: Correlation between 2.5 ppm (¹H) ↔ 15 ppm (¹³C), 5.5 ppm (¹H) ↔ 60 ppm (¹³C), and aromatic ¹H–¹³C pairs.

Determine the structure and explain how each spectral feature supports your conclusion.
solution:
Step 1: Analyze IR data
- 2250 cm⁻¹: Sharp peak indicates nitrile (C≡N) group.
- 1345 and 1155 cm⁻¹: Strong absorptions correspond to symmetric and asymmetric S=O stretches of a sulfone (SO₂) group.
- 3300 cm⁻¹: Broad peak suggests N–H stretch (likely sulfonamide NH₂ or secondary amine).

Step 2: Interpret mass spectrum
- Molecular ion at m/z 333 matches calculated molecular weight (C₁₅H₁₅N₃O₂S₂ = 333 g/mol).
- Fragment at m/z 286: Loss of 47 Da (333 – 286) corresponds to SMe group (S + CH₃ = 32 + 15 = 47), indicating a thioether linkage.

Step 3: Analyze ¹H NMR
- 2.5 ppm (s, 3H): Singlet for methyl group attached to sulfur (S–CH₃).
- 5.5 ppm (d, J=8 Hz, 1H): Doublet for a proton on a carbon adjacent to a nitrogen (C–H coupled to N–H).
- 7.0 ppm (br s, 2H): Broad singlet for exchangeable protons, consistent with sulfonamide NH₂.
- 7.2–7.8 ppm (m, 8H): Two sets of aromatic multiplets (4H each), suggesting two para-substituted benzene rings.

Step 4: Analyze ¹³C NMR and HSQC
- 15 ppm (CH₃): Methyl carbon bonded to sulfur (confirmed by HSQC correlation with 2.5 ppm ¹H).
- 60 ppm (CH): Methine carbon bonded to nitrogen (confirmed by HSQC correlation with 5.5 ppm ¹H).
- 115 ppm (C): Quaternary carbon, likely nitrile (C≡N).
- 125–140 ppm: Aromatic carbons (8 signals for two benzene rings).
- 150 ppm (C): Quaternary carbon, likely aromatic carbon bonded to sulfone group (C–SO₂).

Step 5: Assemble the structure
- Sulfone (SO₂) and NH₂ groups form a sulfonamide (–SO₂NH₂) on one benzene ring.
- Nitrile (C≡N) and thioether (S–CH₃) groups are on the other benzene ring.
- The methine proton (5.5 ppm) connects the two aromatic systems via a C–N bond, forming a secondary amine (–CH(NH)–).

Final structure: CSc1ccc(C(C#N)Nc2ccc(S(N)(=O)=O)cc2)cc1
- Matches all spectral data and molecular formula.

question:
A compound with molecular formula C₁₅H₁₂O₃S₂ exhibits the following spectral data:

IR (cm⁻¹): 3050 (w), 2100 (m), 1600 (s), 1350 (s), 1150 (s), 750 (m)
Mass Spectrum (m/z): 304 (M⁺, 100%), 240 (40%), 157 (30%)
¹H NMR (δ, ppm): 3.05 (s, 1H), 7.15 (d, J=8.5 Hz, 2H), 7.45-7.60 (m, 5H), 7.85 (d, J=8.5 Hz, 2H)
¹³C NMR (δ, ppm): 78.5, 85.0, 122.0, 126.5, 128.0, 129.5, 130.0, 132.5, 135.0, 145.0, 150.0
HSQC: Correlation between δ 3.05 (¹H) and δ 78.5 (¹³C); δ 7.15 (¹H) and δ 122.0 (¹³C); δ 7.85 (¹H) and δ 132.5 (¹³C)

Determine the molecular structure and explain how each spectral feature supports your conclusion.
solution:
Step 1: Analyze molecular formula and IR data
- C₁₅H₁₂O₃S₂ has 10 degrees of unsaturation (rings + π bonds). IR shows:
  - 2100 cm⁻¹: C≡C stretch (alkyne)
  - 1350 & 1150 cm⁻¹: SO₂ asymmetric/symmetric stretches
  - 1600 cm⁻¹: Aromatic C=C
  - 3050 cm⁻¹: Aromatic C-H

Step 2: Interpret mass spectrum
- M⁺ at m/z 304 matches molecular weight
- Fragment at 240: Loss of SO₂ (64 Da) from molecular ion
- Fragment at 157: C₆H₅SO₂⁺ (phenylsulfonyl group)

Step 3: Analyze ¹H NMR
- 3.05 ppm (s, 1H): Terminal alkyne proton (HC≡C-)
- 7.15 ppm (d, 2H) & 7.85 ppm (d, 2H): Para-substituted benzene ring (J=8.5 Hz)
- 7.45-7.60 ppm (m, 5H): Monosubstituted benzene ring

Step 4: Analyze ¹³C NMR and HSQC
- 78.5 & 85.0 ppm: Alkyne carbons (HSQC confirms HC≡C-)
- 122.0 & 132.5 ppm: Aromatic carbons with attached protons (HSQC correlations)
- 145.0 & 150.0 ppm: Quaternary aromatic carbons (likely attached to S/O)

Step 5: Combine evidence
- Alkyne group: HC≡C- (IR, ¹H/¹³C NMR, HSQC)
- Para-disubstituted benzene: Two doublets in ¹H NMR, quaternary carbons at 145 & 150 ppm
- Monosubstituted benzene: Multiplet integrating to 5H, consistent with phenylsulfonyl group (MS fragment)
- SO₂ group: IR, MS fragment at 157

Step 6: Assemble structure
- HC≡C-S- linkage: Alkyne connected to sulfur
- Sulfur attached to para-disubstituted benzene (150 ppm carbon)
- Second benzene attached via sulfonate ester (O-SO₂-Ph)

Final structure: HC≡C-S-Ph(4-O-SO₂-Ph)
(SMILES: C#CCSc1ccc(OS(=O)(=O)c2ccccc2)cc1)

question:
A compound with molecular formula C₆H₉NO₃ exhibits the following spectral data:

**IR (cm⁻¹):** 1740 (s), 1680 (s), 1540 (m), 1250 (m), 1050 (m)
**Mass Spectrum (m/z):** 143 (M⁺, 100%), 128 (M-15), 84 (M-59)
**¹H NMR (δ, ppm):** 3.7 (s, 3H), 4.2 (m, 1H), 2.4–2.6 (m, 2H), 2.0–2.2 (m, 2H), 6.5 (br s, 1H)
**¹³C NMR (δ, ppm):** 170 (C=O), 175 (C=O), 55 (CH), 52 (CH₃), 30 (CH₂), 20 (CH₂)
**HSQC:** Cross-peaks confirm ¹H-¹³C correlations for all protons.

Determine the molecular structure and assign all spectral features to support your conclusion.
solution:
Step 1: Analyze molecular formula and degrees of unsaturation.
- C₆H₉NO₃: Degrees of unsaturation = (2C + 2 - H + N)/2 = (12 + 2 - 9 + 1)/2 = 3. Suggests three double bonds/rings.

Step 2: Interpret IR spectrum.
- 1740 cm⁻¹: Ester C=O stretch.
- 1680 cm⁻¹: Amide C=O stretch (lower than ester due to resonance).
- 1540 cm⁻¹: N-H bending (amide).
- 1250/1050 cm⁻¹: C-O stretches (ester).

Step 3: Analyze mass spectrum.
- M⁺ at 143 matches molecular weight (C₆H₉NO₃ = 143).
- Fragment at 128: Loss of methyl (15 Da, -CH₃ from ester).
- Fragment at 84: Loss of COOCH₃ (59 Da), indicating ester group.

Step 4: Assign ¹H NMR.
- 3.7 ppm (s, 3H): Ester OCH₃ group.
- 4.2 ppm (m, 1H): Methine proton (CH) adjacent to electronegative N and ester.
- 2.4–2.6 ppm (m, 2H) and 2.0–2.2 ppm (m, 2H): Two distinct CH₂ groups in a cyclic structure.
- 6.5 ppm (br s, 1H): Amide N-H proton.

Step 5: Assign ¹³C NMR.
- 170 ppm: Ester carbonyl carbon.
- 175 ppm: Amide carbonyl carbon (higher shift due to ring strain).
- 55 ppm: Methine carbon (CH) bonded to N and ester.
- 52 ppm: OCH₃ carbon.
- 30 ppm and 20 ppm: Two CH₂ carbons in the ring.

Step 6: Combine HSQC and structural clues.
- HSQC confirms OCH₃ (3.7H–52C), CH (4.2H–55C), and CH₂ (2.4–2.6H–30C, 2.0–2.2H–20C) correlations.
- Three degrees of unsaturation: Two C=O groups + one ring.

Step 7: Propose structure.
- Cyclic amide (lactam) with ester substituent: **methyl 5-oxopyrrolidine-2-carboxylate**.
- The five-membered ring explains the CH₂ groups and ring strain on the amide C=O.
- All spectral data align with this structure.

question:
A compound with molecular formula C₁₆H₁₁F₆NO₄ exhibits the following spectroscopic features:

**IR (cm⁻¹):** 3100 (broad), 1735 (sharp), 1700 (sharp), 1330 (strong), 1120 (strong)
**Mass Spectrum:** Molecular ion at m/z 395, base peak at m/z 69
**¹H NMR (δ, ppm):** 3.85 (s, 3H), 4.82 (s, 2H), 6.75 (s, 1H), 7.25 (s, 1H), 7.60 (d, J=8.0 Hz, 2H), 7.95 (s, 1H), 10.2 (br s, 1H)
**¹³C NMR (δ, ppm):** 52.1, 61.3, 112.5, 115.8, 118.2 (q, J=270 Hz), 121.7, 124.5 (q, J=270 Hz), 128.9, 130.1, 132.0, 135.7, 140.3, 162.5, 168.7, 171.2
**HSQC:** Correlations between 3.85 ppm (¹H) and 52.1 ppm (¹³C); 4.82 ppm (¹H) and 61.3 ppm (¹³C); 6.75 ppm (¹H) and 112.5 ppm (¹³C); 7.25 ppm (¹H) and 115.8 ppm (¹³C); 7.60 ppm (¹H) and 128.9 ppm (¹³C)

Determine the molecular structure and assign key spectral features to specific structural motifs.
solution:
### Step-by-Step Analysis:

1. **Molecular Formula Analysis:**
   - C₁₆H₁₁F₆NO₄: Degree of Unsaturation = (2C + 2 - H - X + N)/2 = (32 + 2 - 11 - 6 + 1)/2 = 9. Suggests aromatic rings and/or multiple double bonds.

2. **IR Interpretation:**
   - 3100 cm⁻¹ (broad): O-H stretch (carboxylic acid).
   - 1735 cm⁻¹ (sharp): Ester C=O stretch.
   - 1700 cm⁻¹ (sharp): Carboxylic acid C=O stretch.
   - 1330 and 1120 cm⁻¹ (strong): C-F stretches (CF₃ groups).

3. **Mass Spectrometry:**
   - Molecular ion at m/z 395 matches C₁₆H₁₁F₆NO₄ (calculated: 395.06).
   - Base peak at m/z 69: Characteristic of CF₃⁺ fragment.

4. **¹H NMR Analysis:**
   - 3.85 ppm (s, 3H): Methyl ester (-OCH₃).
   - 4.82 ppm (s, 2H): CH₂ adjacent to electronegative N (N-CH₂-COOH).
   - 6.75 ppm (s, 1H) & 7.25 ppm (s, 1H): Pyrrole ring protons (des shielded by electron-withdrawing groups).
   - 7.60 ppm (d, J=8.0 Hz, 2H): Aromatic protons on phenyl ring (meta to CF₃ groups).
   - 7.95 ppm (s, 1H): Aromatic proton on phenyl ring (para to CF₃ groups).
   - 10.2 ppm (br s, 1H): Carboxylic acid proton (-COOH).

5. **¹³C NMR and HSQC:**
   - 52.1 ppm (HSQC: 3.85 ppm): Ester -OCH₃ carbon.
   - 61.3 ppm (HSQC: 4.82 ppm): N-CH₂-COOH carbon.
   - 112.5 ppm (HSQC: 6.75 ppm) & 115.8 ppm (HSQC: 7.25 ppm): Pyrrole ring carbons with attached protons.
   - 118.2 ppm & 124.5 ppm (q, J=270 Hz): CF₃ carbons (¹⁹F coupling).
   - 128.9 ppm (HSQC: 7.60 ppm): Aromatic carbons on phenyl ring.
   - 162.5 ppm: Ester carbonyl (C=O).
   - 171.2 ppm: Carboxylic acid carbonyl (C=O).

6. **Structure Assembly:**
   - The ester (-COOCH₃) and carboxylic acid (-COOH) groups are confirmed by IR, NMR, and MS.
   - Two CF₃ groups are attached to a phenyl ring (¹³C NMR, IR, MS base peak).
   - The pyrrole ring is substituted at positions 2 (ester), 3 (N-CH₂-COOH), and 4 (phenyl), leaving protons at positions 2 and 4 (¹H NMR).
   - The phenyl ring is 1,3,5-trisubstituted (two CF₃ and one pyrrole), consistent with the 7.60 ppm (d, 2H) and 7.95 ppm (s, 1H) pattern.

**Final Structure:**
Methyl 4-(3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)phenyl)-1-(carboxymethyl)pyrrole-2-carboxylate (SMILES: COC(=O)c1cn(CC(=O)O)cc1-c1cc(C(F)(F)F)cc(C(F)(F)F)c1)

question:
A compound with molecular formula C₁₇H₁₈N₄O₅ exhibits the following spectral data:

IR (cm⁻¹): 3320 (broad), 1705, 1655, 1600, 1520
Mass Spectrum: m/z 359 [M+H]⁺
¹H NMR (δ, ppm): 12.1 (br s, 1H), 9.8 (br s, 1H), 8.2 (d, J=8.5 Hz, 2H), 7.8 (d, J=8.5 Hz, 2H), 7.6 (d, J=8.0 Hz, 2H), 7.4 (d, J=8.0 Hz, 2H), 4.4 (t, J=7.0 Hz, 1H), 2.5-2.7 (m, 2H), 2.1-2.3 (m, 1H), 1.9-2.1 (m, 1H)
HSQC: Correlations between 4.4 ppm (¹H) and 55 ppm (¹³C), 2.5-2.7 ppm (¹H) and 30 ppm (¹³C), 7.4 ppm (¹H) and 128 ppm (¹³C)

Determine the complete structure using integrated spectral analysis. Key considerations should include functional group identification, aromatic substitution patterns, and heteroatom incorporation.
solution:
Step 1: Calculate degree of unsaturation = (2×17 + 2 - 18 + 4)/2 = 11, indicating multiple rings/π systems.

Step 2: IR analysis:
- 3320 cm⁻¹ (broad) indicates OH (carboxylic acid) + NH (amide)
- 1705 cm⁻¹ (sharp) = carboxylic acid C=O
- 1655 cm⁻¹ = amide C=O
- 1600/1520 cm⁻¹ = aromatic C=C

Step 3: MS confirms MW=358 g/mol and suggests carboxylic acid (common loss of CO₂ in fragments).

Step 4: ¹H NMR analysis:
- 12.1 ppm (br s) = carboxylic acid proton
- 9.8 ppm (br s) = amide NH
- Two sets of aromatic doublets (8.2/7.8 and 7.6/7.4 ppm) = two para-substituted benzene rings
- 4.4 ppm (t) = methine proton adjacent to electronegative atom (N or O)
- 2.5-2.7 ppm (m) = methylene protons near carbonyl
- 1.9-2.3 ppm (m) = methylene protons in aliphatic chain

Step 5: HSQC correlations:
- 4.4 ppm (¹H) ↔ 55 ppm (¹³C) = CH-N group
- 2.5-2.7 ppm (¹H) ↔ 30 ppm (¹³C) = CH₂-C=O
- 7.4 ppm (¹H) ↔ 128 ppm (¹³C) = aromatic CH

Step 6: Assemble structure:
- Two para-substituted aromatic rings (NMR coupling patterns)
- Carboxylic acid group (IR + 12.1 ppm)
- Amide linkage (IR + 9.8 ppm)
- Pyrrolidine ring (55 ppm CH-N + aliphatic protons)
- Connection pattern: Carboxylic acid on one benzene, amide-linked to pyrrolidine, which connects to second benzene

Final structure: 5-(4-{[(2S)-2-amino-4-carbamoylbutanoyl]amino}phenyl)-1H-pyridin-2-one-3-carboxylic acid (SMILES: NC(=O)CC[C@H](N)C(=O)Nc1ccc(-c2ccc(C(=O)O)c(=O)[nH]2)cc1)

question:
A compound with molecular formula C₁₂H₁₄O₅S exhibits the following spectroscopic data:

**IR (cm⁻¹):** 3000-2500 (broad), 1710, 1250, 1040, 1600, 1500.
**¹H NMR (δ, ppm):** 7.05 (1H, d, J=8 Hz), 6.95 (1H, d, J=8 Hz), 5.95 (2H, s), 3.95 (2H, s), 3.65 (1H, q, J=7 Hz), 2.25 (3H, s), 1.35 (3H, d, J=7 Hz), 11.5 (1H, broad).
**¹³C NMR (δ, ppm):** 170.5, 148.0, 145.5, 135.0, 128.5, 120.0, 108.0, 102.0, 55.0, 30.0, 20.0, 15.0.
**Mass Spectrum (m/z):** 270 (M⁺, 100%), 179 (base peak).

Using the provided data, determine the structure and explain your reasoning step by step.
solution:
Step 1: Calculate degrees of unsaturation.
Degrees = (2C + 2 - H)/2 = (2×12 + 2 - 14)/2 = 6. Suggests aromatic ring (4°) + 2 additional rings/double bonds.

Step 2: Analyze IR data.
- 1710 cm⁻¹: Carboxylic acid C=O.
- 1250 cm⁻¹: C-O (COOH and methylenedioxy).
- 1040 cm⁻¹: Sulfoxide S=O.
- 1600/1500 cm⁻¹: Aromatic C=C.

Step 3: Interpret mass spectrum.
- M⁺ at 270 confirms molecular weight.
- Base peak at 179: Loss of 91 Da (likely tropylium ion from benzyl-type cleavage).

Step 4: Analyze ¹H NMR.
- 7.05 (d, J=8 Hz) & 6.95 (d, J=8 Hz): Ortho-coupled aromatic protons.
- 5.95 (s): Methylenedioxy (OCH₂O) protons.
- 3.95 (s): CH₂ adjacent to sulfoxide (deshielded).
- 3.65 (q, J=7 Hz) & 1.35 (d, J=7 Hz): Diastereotopic CH and CH₃ (ethyl-type splitting).
- 2.25 (s): Aromatic methyl group.
- 11.5 (broad): Carboxylic acid proton.

Step 5: Analyze ¹³C NMR.
- 170.5: COOH carbonyl.
- 148.0/145.5: Oxygenated aromatic carbons.
- 102.0: OCH₂O carbon.
- 55.0: CH₂ adjacent to sulfoxide.
- 30.0/15.0: CH and CH₃ of isopropyl group.
- 20.0: Aromatic methyl.

Step 6: Integrate HSQC data (implied).
- 5.95 ppm (¹H) ↔ 102.0 ppm (¹³C): OCH₂O.
- 3.95 ppm (¹H) ↔ 55.0 ppm (¹³C): CH₂-SO.
- 3.65 ppm (¹H) ↔ 30.0 ppm (¹³C): CH.
- 1.35 ppm (¹H) ↔ 15.0 ppm (¹³C): CH₃.

Step 7: Assemble structure.
- Benzene ring with methylenedioxy (OCH₂O) → 1,3-benzodioxole.
- Substituents: Aromatic methyl, CH(CH₃)SOCH₂COOH.
- Sulfoxide confirmed by S=O IR and CH₂ deshielding.
- Carboxylic acid confirmed by IR/NMR.

Final Structure: 5-[1-(Methylsulfinyl)ethyl]-6-methyl-1,3-benzodioxole-2-acetic acid (SMILES: Cc1cc2c(cc1C(C)S(=O)CC(=O)O)OCO2).

question:
An unknown compound with molecular formula C₁₃H₈FNO₂S exhibits the following spectral data:

IR (cm⁻¹): 3250 (broad), 1700 (sharp), 1650 (sharp), 1500 (medium), 1250 (medium), 1150 (medium).
Mass spectrum (m/z): 261 (M⁺, 100%), 233 (M-CO, 40%), 163 (M-thiophene carbonyl, 30%).
¹H NMR (δ, ppm): 10.2 (s, 1H, NH), 7.8–7.2 (m, 6H, aromatic), 3.8 (s, 2H, CH₂).
¹³C NMR (δ, ppm): 190 (C=O), 170 (C=O), 165 (C-F), 140–120 (aromatic), 40 (CH₂).
HSQC: Correlation between 3.8 ppm (H) and 40 ppm (C).

Deduce the structure and explain how each spectral feature supports your conclusion.
solution:
Step 1: Calculate degrees of unsaturation. For C₁₃H₈FNO₂S: 
(2C + 2 - H - X + N)/2 = (26 + 2 - 8 - 1 + 1)/2 = 10. This indicates multiple rings/double bonds.

Step 2: Analyze IR data:
- 3250 cm⁻¹ (broad): N-H stretch (amide).
- 1700 and 1650 cm⁻¹: Two carbonyl groups (likely ketone and amide).
- 1250 and 1150 cm⁻¹: C-F stretch and C-O stretch (amide).

Step 3: Mass spectrum confirms molecular weight (261) and fragmentation:
- 233 (M-CO): Loss of a carbonyl group.
- 163 (M-thiophene carbonyl): Loss of C₄H₂OS (thiophene carbonyl fragment).

Step 4: ¹H NMR analysis:
- 10.2 ppm (s, 1H): Deshielded NH (amide).
- 3.8 ppm (s, 2H): CH₂ group adjacent to electron-withdrawing groups (e.g., carbonyl).
- 7.8–7.2 ppm (m, 6H): Aromatic protons (benzene + thiophene).

Step 5: ¹³C NMR and HSQC:
- 190 ppm (C=O): Ketone carbonyl.
- 170 ppm (C=O): Amide carbonyl.
- 165 ppm: Aromatic carbon bonded to fluorine (C-F).
- 40 ppm (CH₂): Confirmed by HSQC correlation with 3.8 ppm proton.

Step 6: Combine data:
- Molecular formula and degrees of unsaturation suggest a fused aromatic system.
- IR and NMR confirm amide (NH, C=O) and ketone (C=O) groups.
- Fluorine substitution is supported by C-F stretch (IR) and ¹³C NMR shift (165 ppm).
- HSQC identifies the CH₂ group adjacent to carbonyl.
- Thiophene is inferred from MS fragmentation (loss of thiophene carbonyl) and aromatic NMR signals.

Final structure: A fluorinated benzamide derivative with a thiophene ketone substituent and a lactam ring. The SMILES O=C1Cc2c(F)cc(C(=O)c3cccs3)cc2N1 matches all spectral data.

question:
Given the molecular formula C₁₄H₁₆N₂O₂ and the following spectral data, deduce the complete molecular structure and provide the SMILES notation:

**IR Spectrum**: Broad peak at 3300 cm⁻¹ (O-H/N-H stretch), strong peak at 1700 cm⁻¹ (C=O), peaks at 1600 and 1450 cm⁻¹ (aromatic C=C).
**Mass Spectrum**: Molecular ion peak at m/z 244, major fragment at m/z 199 (loss of 45 Da).
**¹H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d₆)**: δ 12.1 (br s, 1H, COOH), 10.8 (s, 1H, indole N-H), 7.5–7.0 (m, 5H, aromatic), 4.2 (dd, 1H, J=10.0, 5.0 Hz, Cα-H), 3.2–2.8 (m, 2H, Cβ-H), 2.6–2.4 (m, 2H, Cγ-H), 1.2 (t, 3H, J=7.5 Hz, CH₃).
**¹³C NMR (100 MHz, DMSO-d₆)**: δ 174.2 (C=O), 138.5, 136.2, 128.8, 127.5, 121.0, 119.8, 118.7, 111.2 (aromatic carbons), 55.1 (Cα), 38.9 (Cβ), 28.7 (Cγ), 12.3 (CH₃).
**HSQC**: Correlation between δ 4.2 (¹H) and δ 55.1 (¹³C), and between δ 1.2 (¹H) and δ 12.3 (¹³C).

Integrate all data to determine the structure.
solution:
Step 1: Analyze molecular formula and IR data. The formula C₁₄H₁₆N₂O₂ (degree of unsaturation = 8) suggests aromatic rings and/or multiple double bonds. The IR peaks confirm a carboxylic acid (3300, 1700 cm⁻¹) and aromatic system (1600, 1450 cm⁻¹).

Step 2: Examine mass spectrum. The m/z 244 molecular ion matches the formula. The fragment at m/z 199 corresponds to loss of COOH (45 Da), indicating a carboxylic acid group.

Step 3: Interpret ¹H NMR. The 12.1 ppm singlet confirms COOH. The 10.8 ppm singlet is an indole N-H. The 7.5–7.0 ppm multiplet (5H) indicates a monosubstituted benzene ring. The 4.2 ppm doublet of doublets (Cα-H) suggests a chiral center adjacent to N. The 1.2 ppm triplet (3H) is a terminal CH₃ group.

Step 4: Analyze ¹³C NMR. The 174.2 ppm peak confirms COOH. Aromatic carbons (138.5–111.2 ppm) align with an indole and benzene ring. The 55.1 ppm carbon (Cα) is attached to N, while 12.3 ppm is the CH₃.

Step 5: Use HSQC. The correlation between δ 4.2 (¹H) and 55.1 (¹³C) confirms the Cα-H assignment. The δ 1.2/12.3 ppm correlation identifies the ethyl group’s terminal CH₃.

Step 6: Assemble the structure. The data matches a tetrahydro-β-carboline scaffold with a carboxylic acid at C3, an ethyl group at C1, and an indole fused to a piperidine ring. The stereochemistry ([C@@H]) is inferred from the coupling pattern of Cα-H.

Final structure: CC[C@@H]1N[C@@H](C(=O)O)Cc2c1[nH]c1ccccc21 (SMILES).

question:
A compound with molecular formula C₁₃H₁₅NO₄ exhibits the following spectral data:

IR (cm⁻¹): 3350 (broad), 1600 (sharp), 1250 (sharp), 1050 (sharp)
Mass Spectrum: m/z 249 (M⁺), 234 (M⁺-CH₃), 192 (M⁺-C₄H₈O₂)
¹H NMR (δ, ppm): 7.85 (d, J=5.2 Hz, 1H), 7.20 (s, 1H), 6.95 (d, J=5.2 Hz, 1H), 6.80 (s, 1H), 4.85 (s, 1H), 3.90 (s, 3H), 3.75-3.85 (m, 2H), 3.50-3.65 (m, 2H), 1.80-2.10 (m, 4H)
¹³C NMR (δ, ppm): 158.2, 152.1, 149.3, 145.7, 129.4, 117.6, 112.8, 109.5, 72.3, 67.8, 56.1, 31.2, 25.8
HSQC: Correlations between 7.85 ppm (¹H) and 149.3 ppm (¹³C), 6.95 ppm (¹H) and 112.8 ppm (¹³C), 3.90 ppm (¹H) and 56.1 ppm (¹³C)

Determine the structure and explain how each spectral feature supports your conclusion.
solution:
Step 1: Calculate degrees of unsaturation. For C₁₃H₁₅NO₄: (2×13 + 2 + 1 - 15)/2 = 7. This indicates multiple rings/π bonds.

Step 2: Analyze IR data. The 3350 cm⁻¹ broad peak indicates O-H (hydroxyl). Peaks at 1600 cm⁻¹ (C=C) and 1250/1050 cm⁻¹ (C-O stretches) suggest aromatic/ether functionalities.

Step 3: Mass spectrometry. Molecular ion at m/z 249 matches C₁₃H₁₅NO₄. Loss of CH₃ (15 Da) gives 234, indicating a methoxy group. Loss of C₄H₈O₂ (88 Da) suggests a tetrahydropyran ring fragmentation.

Step 4: ¹H NMR analysis. The 3.90 ppm singlet (3H) corresponds to a methoxy group. Aromatic protons appear as doublets (7.85 and 6.95 ppm, J=5.2 Hz) and singlets (7.20 and 6.80 ppm), indicating a fused heteroaromatic system. The 4.85 ppm singlet (1H) is a hydroxyl proton. Multiplets at 3.75-3.85 ppm and 1.80-2.10 ppm correspond to tetrahydropyran ring protons.

Step 5: ¹³C NMR and HSQC. The 56.1 ppm carbon (HSQC correlation with 3.90 ppm) confirms methoxy. Aromatic carbons appear between 109.5-158.2 ppm. The 72.3 ppm carbon (HSQC with 4.85 ppm) is the hydroxyl-bearing carbon. The 67.8 ppm carbon is another oxygenated carbon in the tetrahydropyran ring.

Step 6: Assemble structure. The methoxy group (3.90 ppm, 56.1 ppm) is attached to a nitrogen-containing aromatic ring (pyridine, based on 158.2 ppm carbon). The fused furan ring (112.8 ppm, HSQC with 6.95 ppm) connects to a hydroxylated tetrahydropyran (72.3 ppm, 67.8 ppm). The 192 Da fragment in MS confirms the tetrahydropyran loss.

Final Structure: 7-Methoxy-2-(4-hydroxytetrahydro-2H-pyran-4-yl)furo[3,2-b]pyridine (SMILES: COc1nccc2cc(C3(O)CCOCC3)oc12)

question:
A compound with molecular formula C14H13F6N7O exhibits the following spectral data:

IR (cm⁻¹): 3350 (broad), 1680, 1580, 1150, 3100
Mass Spectrum (m/z): 409 (M⁺), 334 (M-75), 353 (M-56), 259 (M-150)
¹H NMR (δ, ppm): 8.5 (s, 1H), 8.2 (s, 1H), 7.8 (s, 1H), 6.5 (s, 2H), 3.8-3.6 (m, 4H), 2.1-1.9 (m, 4H), 10.2 (br s, 1H)
¹³C NMR (δ, ppm): 168, 155, 150, 145, 140, 130, 125, 120, 115, 50, 30
HSQC: Correlations between 3.8-3.6 ppm (H) ↔ 50 ppm (C), 2.1-1.9 ppm (H) ↔ 30 ppm (C), 8.2 ppm (H) ↔ 150 ppm (C), 7.8 ppm (H) ↔ 145 ppm (C), 6.5 ppm (H) ↔ 155 ppm (C)

Determine the molecular structure and assign key spectral features to structural elements.
solution:
Step 1: Analyze molecular formula (C14H13F6N7O)
- Degrees of unsaturation: (2C+2-H+N)/2 = (28+2-13+7)/2 = 12 → highly unsaturated (aromatic rings, multiple bonds).

Step 2: IR interpretation
- 3350 cm⁻¹ (broad): NH₂ group
- 1680 cm⁻¹: Amide C=O
- 1580 cm⁻¹: C=N (heteroaromatic ring)
- 1150 cm⁻¹: C-F (CF₃ groups)
- 3100 cm⁻¹: Aromatic C-H

Step 3: Mass spectrometry
- M⁺ = 409 matches molecular formula
- Fragment m/z 334 (M-75): Loss of CF₃ (75 Da)
- Fragment m/z 353 (M-56): Loss of pyrrolidine (C₄H₈, 56 Da)
- Fragment m/z 259: Loss of both CF₃ and pyrrolidine

Step 4: ¹H NMR analysis
- 6.5 ppm (s, 2H): NH₂ group
- 10.2 ppm (br s, 1H): Amide NH
- 8.5 ppm (s, 1H): Pyrazole NH
- 8.2 ppm (s, 1H) & 7.8 ppm (s, 1H): Aromatic protons (pyrimidine ring)
- 3.8-3.6 ppm (m, 4H) & 2.1-1.9 ppm (m, 4H): Pyrrolidine ring CH₂ groups

Step 5: ¹³C NMR and HSQC
- 168 ppm: Amide carbonyl
- 155 ppm (HSQC correlation to NH₂): Aromatic carbon bonded to NH₂
- 150 ppm & 145 ppm (HSQC correlations to aromatic H): Pyrimidine ring carbons
- 140 ppm & 120 ppm: CF₃-substituted aromatic carbons
- 130 ppm & 125 ppm: Other aromatic carbons
- 50 ppm & 30 ppm (HSQC correlations to pyrrolidine H): Pyrrolidine ring carbons

Step 6: Structure assembly
- NH₂ and amide groups on a pyrimidine ring (δ 155, 150, 145 ppm)
- CF₃ groups on aromatic rings (IR 1150 cm⁻¹, ¹³C 140/120 ppm)
- Pyrrolidine ring (HSQC correlations, ¹H/¹³C shifts)
- Pyrazole ring with NH (δ 8.5 ppm, ¹³C 125 ppm)

Final structure: 2-Amino-4-(trifluoromethyl)-5-(pyrrolidin-1-yl)-N-(3-(trifluoromethyl)-1H-pyrazol-5-yl)pyrimidine-6-carboxamide
(SMILES: Nc1nc(C(F)(F)F)c(N2CCCC2)nc1C(=O)Nc1cc(C(F)(F)F)n[nH]1)

question:
A compound with molecular formula C17H21N5O2S exhibits the following spectral data:

IR (cm⁻¹): 3350 (broad), 3180, 1685, 1605, 1520, 1250, 1050, 700
Mass Spectrum: m/z 359 (M⁺, 100%), 272 (M⁺-87), 91 (C7H7⁺)
¹H NMR (δ, ppm): 1.20 (t, 3H, J=7.0 Hz), 1.75 (m, 2H), 2.55 (t, 2H, J=7.0 Hz), 3.45 (q, 2H, J=7.0 Hz), 3.60 (t, 2H, J=6.5 Hz), 5.50 (s, 2H), 6.80 (br s, 2H), 7.20-7.40 (m, 5H), 8.10 (s, 1H)
¹³C NMR (δ, ppm): 14.5, 25.8, 30.2, 45.6, 60.1, 118.7, 127.2, 128.5, 129.1, 136.8, 140.2, 150.5, 155.3, 162.4, 168.9
HSQC: Correlations between 1.20 ppm (14.5 ppm C), 3.45 ppm (60.1 ppm C), 5.50 ppm (45.6 ppm C), 8.10 ppm (140.2 ppm C)

Determine the complete structure using all spectral data. Show step-by-step reasoning.
solution:
Step 1: Analyze molecular formula (C17H21N5O2S)
- Degrees of unsaturation = (2×17 + 2 - 21 - 0 + 5)/2 = 10
- Indicates multiple rings/aromatic systems

Step 2: IR Interpretation
- 3350 cm⁻¹ (broad): OH/NH₂ groups
- 1685 cm⁻¹: Carbonyl (C=O)
- 1605/1520 cm⁻¹: Aromatic C=C
- 1250 cm⁻¹: C-O stretch
- 700 cm⁻¹: C-S stretch

Step 3: Mass Spectrometry
- M⁺ at m/z 359 confirms molecular weight
- Fragment at 272 (M⁺-87): Loss of C5H11O (ethoxypropyl group)
- Base peak at 91: Benzyl cation (C7H7⁺)

Step 4: ¹H NMR Analysis
- 1.20 ppm (t, 3H) & 3.45 ppm (q, 2H): Ethyl group (OCH₂CH₃)
- 1.75 ppm (m, 2H) & 2.55 ppm (t, 2H): Propyl chain (CH₂CH₂S)
- 3.60 ppm (t, 2H): OCH₂ adjacent to oxygen
- 5.50 ppm (s, 2H): Benzyl CH₂ group
- 6.80 ppm (br s, 2H): NH₂ group
- 7.20-7.40 ppm (m, 5H): Monosubstituted benzene
- 8.10 ppm (s, 1H): Purine C8-H

Step 5: ¹³C NMR & HSQC
- 14.5 ppm & 60.1 ppm: Ethyl group (CH₃ & CH₂)
- 45.6 ppm: Benzyl CH₂
- 140.2 ppm: Quaternary aromatic carbon (C8)
- 168.9 ppm: Carbonyl carbon (C2=O)
- 155.3 ppm: Thioether carbon (C6-S)

Step 6: Structure Assembly
1. Benzyl group (C7H7) confirmed by m/z 91 and 5.50 ppm (s, 2H)
2. Ethoxypropyl chain (C5H11O) from NMR and m/z 87 loss
3. Purine core indicated by:
   - 10 degrees of unsaturation
   - Characteristic C8-H at 8.10 ppm
   - Carbonyl at C2 (168.9 ppm)
   - Thioether at C6 (155.3 ppm)
